text: Thanks JC. Nice aroma, kind of smells like a black IPA. Hoppy, bit of spice maybe, mint maybe. Taste is interesting, much more porter like. Bit spicy, dry, light chili, dry and bit smoky. Enjoyable!

Thanks Virby44 for the bottle! Poured into a taster showing half a finger of latte colored foam wit pitch black center and no rims. 

The nose shows earthy hops with subdued smoky rauchbier notes. 

The palate is highly carbonated and light bodied yet foamy. The palate is hoppy with a light dark malt mid-palate. Ending shows a hoppy bitterness with prickly alcohol.

Dark brown color. Lots of chocolate cake, spice, cacao nibs very dry nose. Hoppy, ash chocolate, spice, cacao nibs and slightly sour mouth. Lingering chocolate mole and horechatta finish. Very interesting. Very good Christmas beer.

Black color with brown head. Aroma is really fragrant and floral with nice chocolate in the background. Taste follows, really nice acacia flower notes, chocolate, slightly sweet but finishes with a nice coffee roastiness. Body is on the light side but its quite smooth on the palate. Really nice porter, quite different from all others I tasted so far.
Excellent dark pour from a bomber. Small tan head. Sweet chocolate and coffee notes. Even light mouth feel. Slight hop bite in the finish. Really well ballanced porter!

Tasted on tap at Crown Liquors. It pours an opaque brown with a light brown head. Robust chocolate hop aroma with a well balanced hop and chocolate malt taste. This is one smooth and delicious porter, perfect winter brew.

Bottled on 11-1-16. 22 oz bottle poured, with a huge thanks to Prufrockstar for this bottle. Always a treat, and you sir, are the man. The final Christmas celebration of the year, happens today, and it might be my favorite of them all! Pours black with a cola tan fizz head. A moderate, roasted, almost smokey malt aroma. Flavor is a mellow impression, toasted malt. Has brown sugar hints, and a nice milk chocolate, but light. Toasted finish. I love how mellow this beer is up front, but ends on a huge roasted note. Very pleasant porter. A Christmas beer that refuses to be really sweet and excessively added with random stuff. Just the brown sugar, which is perfect for my liking. Bold chocolate. Fantastic porter.

Bottle. Pours black nic thick brown head. The smell is daArk fruit. Chocolate. The palate is thick creamy. The taste is fruit hops. Citrus. With chocolate and sugar. Chocolate dark fruity. Awesome porter. Cant wait to try the BA version.

Dark brown with tannish head... aroma of chocolate malts, citrus, brown sugar, spices... flavor is light bodied and crushable, lots of chocolate malts, citrus, brown sugar and light spices and hops on finish... excellent porter 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (750 ml). Nose of smoke, earthiness, and pine. Smoky malt with earthy pine. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pitch black with a lasting foamy light beige head. Aroma is of chocolate, caramel, nuts, hint of spices and dark fruits. Taste is of chocolate, caramel, coffee, dark fruits, oats, sugar, spices. Sticky oily mouthfeel, medium carbonation.

Bomber shared. Pours a deep brown with a finger of foam that lingers. Lots of bakers chocolate in the nose with some milk chocolate, cinnamon and nutmeg notes. Roasted cacao nib and yoohoo on the palate. Well-balanced, but leans a tad sweet with more christmas baking spice notes. Finish is dry with a touch of roasted malt and hoppy bitterness. Solid.

Rated while house hunting Indianapolis IN. Dark malt color great thick retention. Big aromas of hop/malt, BAM!! I get pine, toasted malt, med smoke, slight wood and molasses. The hop/malt pair very well. Flavors med to strong pine, just a little stronger than the med malt profile of roast, wood, and slight molasses. Med to high sweetness. Not terribly complex but just enough to be darn tasty!

Pours opaque coffee sable with a light tan head. Aroma delivers roast malt, hay and anchovy tones. Flavor features roast malt, molasses, anchovy and wood notes. Anchovies? Mouthfeel brings average body and OK fizz to the table, er, bar. Here comes Alpha Klaus, here comes Alpha Klaus, right down Alpha Klaus Lane.
Dark opaque brown, light tan head. Coffee, tobacco, pine, a bit of soy sauce. Some spice, quite bitter, somewhat dry. Heavy body, chewy, slightly oily. Good.
@ Eddan 16-12-3: Toner av choklad och lite kryddor. Fin fyllighet och len eftersmak. Stabil

Bottle bought in Chicago in February 2016. Black with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and some light hops. Similar taste, also some chocolate and hints of spices. The body was around medium. A tasty one.
On draft at Bru Burger. Lots of chocolate with some sugar. Sweet with hop bitterness to balance it.

bottle from an indiana rip and run and enjoyed in my Illinois hotel room that majically had some nice glasses to use. pours the part, dark, tan head. solid chocolate malt, some citrus. yeah buddy. medium body with a lingering finish.
Dark, Brown pour w a tan head. The aroma has chocolate and some light grassy hops. It has a medium body with smooth texture and lively carbonation. The taste is bitter with a dry finish.

Pours black with tall, brown head; lacing present throughout the duration of the drink. Upfront aroma is chocolate, espresso, vanilla bean, and malt; definitely some roast elements at play as well. Taste is dark chocolate, vanilla, somewhat smokier than the nose, slightly bitter hoppiness (it's a 3F offering after all). Good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Given to me by a co-worker. Poured from bomber. Pours dark brown almost black with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt , smoky wood, roasted coffee and chocolate. Flavor is rich roasted malt, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla and chocolate. Truly an amazing beer. Definately one of the best beers Ive ever had.
Really nice brew. Pours black with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is roasted chocolate with a hint of hops and spices. Silky smooth with a light hop bite.

Bottle. Trade with Kermis. Thanks Chris. Pours nearly black with a small settling creamy beige head and lacings. Nose has roast, coffee, zest - orange peel. Dry and roasted bitter flavor with coffee and dark fruit, chocolate plus a faint dusty hoppy note. My guess is that its 2 or 3 years old so the hops pretty much vanished. Smooth and light bodied - suitable. Would be fun to try fresh which I guess would give it some other strings to play. Nice

Tasting at Hackneys Printers Row. Roasty, spicy, piney aroma. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolatey, dried ginger, Christmas spices, chocolate chip cookie. Creamy palate. Dry finish. Excellent seasonal.

Pours a deep black from the bomber with thin ring of tan brown head that leaves light lace. Aroma of mild coffee roast and spice. Taste is more toward light sweet malts and chocolate, hint of vanilla. Interesting, really nice
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 At the daily. This was fantastic. It got the roast level, the hops, the malt just right, a little rich but stiff drinkable even a little minerally. Serving: Tap

Aroma - rich roast, dark chocolate, coffee,orange zest, and potent citrus hops
Appearance - black body, beige head, quality lacing
Taste - carmalized sugar, roast, citrus, coffee, dark chocolate.
Palate - medium to full body, texture is creamy, soft carbonation, roast astringency that is long.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber dated 11/11/15. Aromas of heavily roasted and smoked malts with some pine needles. Taste is charred malts, sugar, chocolate, dates on the tip of the tongue. Middle of the mouth is where a tea like and pine hop flavor appears. Finish is a resinous after taste.

Aroma is roasty, somewhat light, a lot of toasted malt, an earthy hop presence. Appearance is dark brown, light tan head, thin. Taste is different. Halfway between a porter and black IPA, the beer is having an identity crisis. Roasted malt character, earthy hops, and not much else. Mouthfeel is thin, medium body and carbonation. Overall, this is not anywhere close to what I expected. No chocolate or sugar, just a standard porter with a hop profile. Much like Avery New World Porter.

Opaque pour with sandy head. Nose of cocoa, tons of ripe raisin and date, coffee, toffee, American citrus and dank hops. Flavor is fairly hoppy, some vegetable/herbal tones, clean and balanced body, fairly active carbonation. Solid porter, fairly clean, not cloying. Good. Standard porter made well.

Purchased from a liquor store cooler in July 2015. Bottled in 2014 (exact days and month are blurred out). Poured in to a tulip-snifter.

Look - Tan with white swirls in head (like an espresso head). It is thick for the pour with very fine, creamy bubbles. The body is dark black. Head stuck around for a bit and left lacing. Very tasty looking beer. 

Smell - Hoppy and malty. A lot of chocolate and coffee once the hop aroma gives up. There is a smell here I cant identify. I dont know if it is a combination of the hops and chocolate that I dont pick up in a Black IPA. I best describe it as the chewy end of gum that has lost its flavor. 

Taste - No Christmas spice as expected. Chocolate and coffee. Hops linger throughout but not overpowering (maybe because of the late pour). 

Feel - Very creamy but not too heavy. Bitterness does not bite the tongue. No carbonation bomb. 

Overall - This is not a Christmas beer, so I did not get my Christmas in July. This is, however, a beer that is on its way to being a Black IPA but still holds true to everything good in a porter. Thumbs up for the Mexican sugar!

22oz bottle into tulip. Minneapolis. 3 yr old bottle. 

Pours black with small rim of offwhite head. 

Aroma is fairly muted. Chocolatey, some coffee, lots of roasted notes. a little leathery. spices have died down a bit. 

Taste is sweet. Some bittering hops to balance. 

Body is medium-full. Carbonation is fairly lively for the style. Thicker texture. Long, rich finish.

27/IV/15 - 22Fl. Oz. bottle @ my country ticks and pulled pork sandwiches tasting - BB: n/a, bottled: XI/13/14 (2015-541)  Thanks to ElManana for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark brown beer, creamy beige head, bit adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: very roasted, some citrus, orange peel, mocha, cocoa powder. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: sweet start, caramel, citrus, mocha, little bitter, very fruity. Aftertaste: mocha, caramel, fruity, sweet, peaches, some chocolate, vanilla, cocoa powder.
Bottle. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasted malty base, mild sweetness, hints of smoked malts, faint chocolate, and faint hoppy bitterness. Good, not great.

22 oz Bomber. Tasted on 5/10/15. Bottle from West Lakeview Liquor. I'm not always a big porter fan but this one was really nice. Great nose followed by a great very complex taste that wasn't sweet but definitely was too bitter either. Really enjoyed this one.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark brown color with tan colored head. Roasted malt, coffee, raw cocoa, and some dark fruit on the nose; follows onto the palate. Interestingly complex. Finishes with roast.

Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, hops. Hoppy flavour, coffee, caramel, light tropical fruits. Finish coffee, tropical fruits, caramel, fresh hops. Nice!! (from 65cL bottle @ Tims country ticks and pulled pork sandwiches tasting. Thanks for sharing, ElManana!)
Bottle at "Pulled-pork-tasting" at tderoeck's place. Thanks myself for bringing the bottle! Coffee, hoppy, exotic fruits, roast, roast and roast. Nice!

Bitter bite of chocolate here with light tempered roast. Black pour with good head. Bitter finish. Hint of rooty herbal kind of aroma in this that puts a unique zing on things. Pretty easy on palate, especially considering alcohol content. Bottle at local option.

22 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Trade from a friend, thanks Daniel! Bottled 11/13/2014. Black with just under two fingers of light tan head. Nice webby lacing. Aromas of roast, a bit of licorice, dark chocolate, floral, pine. Tastes of dark chocolate, floral, pine, roast. Tasty but seems more like a black IPA.
22oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Some spice in the aroma. Medium hop bitterness though some harsh flavors.

Pours a thick black with tan head. Aromas are very meaty. Crazy resin in this one. Also brown sugar and notes of chocolate. Flavors are dominated by resin and Mexican sugar with hints of chocolate. The mouthfeel is awesome. Weird... But in a good way.

Bottle thanks to Rob. Pours a dark brown with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is dark chocolate and floral hop. Thin mouth with nice roast, dark chocolate and resin hop finsh. Very good.
Bottle cheers to Rob. This had a distinct cocoa powdery feel to it. Very dry and herbal. It isnt completely amazing but I can see why it is so highly regarded. Drinks superbly. Very nice

From bomber. Pours black with a medium thickness dense foam head. Big aroma of coffee and chocolate malts. Taste is delicious coffee and chocolate. Full mouthfeel that just feels perfect. Light carbonation. This is a delicious and fine beer. One of the best porters Ive ever enjoyed.
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомен& его всем. пожалуй& обратит& его. очень хорошо!
bottle. black with one finger head. rich porter wit substantial chocolate. a bit sweet with the hops youd expect from 3F.
Bomber. Deep brown with a tan head. Malt and hops. Clean and hoppy. Black ipaish?

Pours nearly black w/ a thin tan head that leaves a good ring of lacing. Im kind of in love w/ the in your face hop aroma that has just a subtle chocolate undertone. The taste is of a chocolate porter up front & finishes w/ a huge hop bang! Easily one of the most unique porters Ive had & highly recommended!

Tasted from draft. Pours black with a beige head. Very complex beer. Aroma of chocolate, earthy grasses and grains and pine. Taste of chocolate, coffee, hint of coffee and caramel, pine, a little stone fruit and dark fruits. Great tasting and interesting beer. Moderate bitterness with great well balanced malt backbone. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On Tap at Millstone BBQ near Logan Ohio. Alpha Klaus is a deep dark brown beer with a thinner head of small white bubbles. Nose is Rich roasted dark chocolate goodness with some interesting hops going on. Taste was mildly to medium sweet with a good amount of spruce. Body was somewhat lively. finish was a good warming with a touch of hop bitterness. a very different and interesting porter.
Really nice porter on tap. Smooth with nice chocolate, coffee and malt flavors. Another great beer from FFF.
This to me makes an incredible holiday brew. Pours nice and dark, dark brown with a light color head. Tasty brew and enjoyable.

Poured from a 22 ounce bottle into a nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Pours a dark cola brown, almost black, with a 2 finger creamy medium tan head. Nice head retention and lacing.

Smell: Dark roasted malt with lots of hops and a touch of chocolate.

Taste: Piney and grassy hops up front followed by roasted malt and a hint of chocolate in the middle before ending with more piney and grassy hops. Aftertaste is fairly bitter with just a touch of semisweet chocolate. The flavor profile is nothing like any porter Ive ever had.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a fairly high amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. Youll have no difficulty finishing off a bomber on your own.

Overall: A good beer overall, but not really my idea of a porter. I also dont understand the Christmas connection with this one, but maybe it fits with 3 Floyds motto of "Its Not Normal." This one is definitely worth trying.
Quite hoppy, quite sweet, quite not my thing. Just weirdly citrusy and earthy and sweet and slightly smoky and all over the place but not anywhere I particularly love.

Pours opaque dark mahogany with a thick dark tan head. Aroma is strong pine with a hint of roasted malt. Slick on the tongue with a medium mouth feel. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate and a ton of hops. Really was hoping for more of a porter and got a black IPA.

bomber from trade; probably cellared 6-9 mos; should have done longer. This is a complex beer but wasnt right for me - just ok. many aromas - vanilla, roast from malts and coffee - maybe a little vinous aroma. Taste was ok in beginning - like aroma; but ended with too much hops - roasted hop combo that didnt work for me. disappointed as I really enjoy this style.

Poured from bomber into tulip. I don't know what I was expecting with this but I was unpleasantly surprised. I really wanted to enjoy a porter but this beer was all about the hops. There were some roastiness in there too but I struggled to find the porter base or anything that said "christmas". Really this was much more akin to a black ipa. I guess I shouldn't have been surprised considering this was FFF.

Bottle shared in Hoboken. Pours deep brown with a frothy beige head. The nose holds well toasted malts, some pine, orange rind. Medium sweet flavor with nice earthy bitterness, cocoa, roast, baked pine. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly ashy on the finish with some ripe orange, pine, well toasted bread. Quite nice.

Pours black with a decent mocha head. Light lacing. Has a coffee, roasted malts, herbal, and rich chocolate aroma. Nice and malty upfront that finished slightly bitter. Flavors of dark chocolate, roasted malts, woody notes, spices, and sweet caramel. Medium body that was smooth and creamy on the palate. Was really pleased with this one!

Tap at Tap House. Near black with a tin ring with medium lacing. Spruce, resiny hops, malty and a light chocolate aroma. Taste has a light dry bitterness that hangs on. Medium body with a fizzy, creamy feel.
A very different twist to the traditional Christmas porters! Loved the hop aroma to this porter!

Really good another fantastic beer from three 
 Floyd's. I wish it was a little less hoppy. But still a great find.

Dec 14 the local chi town... Pours black as night, brownish head, not much of it. Stayed around edges. Aroma is coffee, licorice, hints of chocolate. First sip tasty, fills mouth, but not overpowering. Leaves little aftertaste. A very good porter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bomber bottle poured into pint glass. Great malt.aroma. Pours an opaque brownish black with a tan head that dissipates at a quick rate. Tastes really smooth. Malty up front with a perfectly sweet balanced finish. Great porter. Recomnended.

Bomber from Savor Growl. Black pour with a big frothy tan head and lacy stick. Aroma of herbal, citrus, cocoa, woody. Tastes are cocoa, orange, dark chocolate, pine, burnt roasted malt. Thin to medium palate. Very drinkable.

Container / location
APPEARANCE  perfectly black, excellent light brown foamy head.
NOSE - surprisingly hoppy fro an Xmas ale.
FLAVOR - like a black ipa.
NOTES - Apparently this is the first black ipa. ok flavor for a christmas porter.
22oz bottle. Black color with beige head. Coffee and hoppy aroma. Smooth coffee and chocolate taste that ends with bitter hops. This is excellent.

Poured a black colour with a soft tan head. Aroma is rich with hops amd roasted malts. Flavor was an earthy and citrus hops with a slight bitterness blended with roasted malts with hinys of vanilla. Medium to heavy bodiex brew with low carbonation ending in a dry bitter finish. Interesting beer if nothing else.
Aroma of chocolate and spices, taste is chocolate, spices, nutmeg, sugary sweetness, some hops, overall really good!
Pours black with tan head. Aroma is very sweet..chocolate. Lots of sweet sugary caramel roast chocolate goodness. Very complex, awesome.

クリスマスポ                                                  
深く香ばしい&     
濃いけど飲み&

bomber shared. poured a dark brown with mocha head. the aroma was hoppy which was good, roasted malts, chocolate. the flavor was blended very nicely was little apprehensive at first but the flavors worked with the roasted malts, chocolate and hops. the chocolate was not bitter enough to offset the hops. great job 3F.

From a 22oz bottle, poured very dark brown medium head. Smell malty, slight chocolate with some hops. Taste some chocolate, licorice, hops slight vanilla. A very different type of porter but in a good way.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a 12 oz bottle with another great FFF label. 

Excellent aroma from this opaque, very dark red-brown ale. 

Good, smooth feel.

tons os strange american hops" is right. not quite what youd wxpect from the style...uberhoppy...a little thin, but very smooth bodied. chocolate, roasted coffee, and an abnormal amount of hops. good stuff."
Bottle from unknown via Kyler. Pours an opaque brown/black. Aroma roasty, sweet, chocolate. Body lively and roasty, slightly bitter baking chocolate finish, lovely.

Black pour with a khaki/tan soapy/creamy head and lots of sticky lacing ... aroma of heavily roasted coffee, chocolate malts and lots of citrusy hops ... taste is a burst of citrusy hops, chocolate malts, bitter roasted coffee and a bit of sweetness with a nice bitter bite .... very balanced flavor profile .... finish is dry roasted, hoppy with a lingering bitterness ... mouthfeel is slick and oily ... very well done
Had this one sitting around for a while. A bit out of season but a nice change of pace. This is a bold porter. Strong roasted, coffee, chocolate, flavor which is complemented by a big hop finish.

650 ml bottle shared with the Quebec City crew. Pours black with a resilient beige head. Aroma is chocolate, mint, spices. Flavor is chocolate, mint, coffee, and something Im unable to read about 6 months after I wrote it. Which should be a reminder that ratebeer backlogs should never be kept for so long. Finish is hoppy and herbal. Medium body, weak carbonation.

From bomber (thanks, Schaefer!)

Pours a nice dark brown with a finger or so of tan head. Dark, almost burnt malt aroma. Burnt malt dominates the flavor, and this beer suffers from the same thing most porters suffer... Teasing of a richness that the style just can't uphold. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown pour with a medium body and average carbonation. Strong anise and molasses aroma and taste, roasted malt, dark chocolate, and fairly bitter hops.

Javoue avoir été déçu par ce classique de 3 Floyds. Cette bière est brune foncée avec une belle mousse beige. Le nez est riche et profond avec ses notes de malt, de caramel, de toffee et dalcool. La bouche est mince, beaucoup plus mince que ce que le nez laissait présager. Cest agréable mais sûrement sur-évalué.
Not much to dislike about this one. Pours perfectly, nice aroma, pleasing chocolate taste. Doesnt have the nasty sting that some imperials have.
22 oz bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black with a tan head. Smell is roasted malts, citrus hops, chocolate. Taste is the same; roaste malts, hops chocolate. Medium body, Nice bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2015 Served: 22oz bottle
Look: pours a dark brown color with a dark tan head. Leaves some lacing on the side of the glass. 
Smell: fruity smell. Dark fruits, chocolate. Strong alcohol smell as it warms up.
Taste: dark beer taste like a porter should. Hints of coffe and chocolate
Feel: slightly heavy. Great carbonation. 
Overall: good overall balance. Love the color, lacing. Great flavor.
First Drank: Mom and Dad's XMAS eve 2013
Vintage: 2013

Look: pours a dark black. Tan head. Can't see through at all.
Smell: smoked malts. Oranges. Citrus fruit.
Taste: oranges. Smoked malts. 
Feel: medium low carbonation. Slight bitterness in the middle. 
Overall: nice beer. Like the way they combine the malts and the hops. Nicely balanced. 
First drank: xmas 2014 Mom & Dad's
Vintage: 2014

[Bottle] Pours jet black in color with a rocky brown head. Nose is of pine, zesty hops, roasty malts and light coffee. Heavy molasses and burnt caramel throughout the taste. Dark brown sugar, piney hops and light tobacco/earthiness. Chalky mouthfeel, but with a more syrupy texture to it. Big and bitter finish. Nice! Tasting notes from 2/2014.

Merci à Hammy78 pour cette bombe. Un corps bien noir sur lequel se forme une mousse brune presque indestructible. La dentelle laissée sur la paroi ressemble à un relief montagneux. Au nez, les houblons percent difficilement le mur malté et rôti. Sur les papilles, le chocolat, le café et le caramel foncé sont traversés par des flaveurs de houblons fruités et mentholés. En bouche, cest bien crémeux. Le corps nest jamais trop dense. En finale, cest sec avec une amertume construite à la fois par le travail des grains et le travail des houblons.
(tap) very dark brown colour with a small brown head; aromas of molasses, roast; balanced flavour with a long light bitter finish
22oz bottle pours dark brown with a slight red hue, thick brown head and little lacing. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, and hops. Slightly bitter flavor. Delicious!

A - pours a dark rich brown with 1 finger tan head that leaves a light ring. S - i dont really get the christmas in the smell. Aroma is almost all hops, soap, floral, bitter citrus and resin. some dark malts, candied dates, cigarettes, coal and toasted malts. M - medium body with sharp carb. water mf with a dry bitter end. hoppy. T - this is a dark dipa? soapy and resiny hops come on first. some bitter citrus, dried grasses. The chocolate and doughy malts are muddled in there with the hops somewhere Im sure of it. Toasted malts, bitter grasses and resin end this. O - not what I was expecting at all. wheres the xmas angle? wheres the this is not an IPA angle? The bitter citrusy hops fight with the porter.

Bottle from a recent trade. Small snifters at Peter and Gails house. Pours a very dark brown, black with a slight off-white head. The aroma is complex with chocolate, vanilla, spices of cinnamon and nutmeg, roasted malts, Brazil nuts, wood barrel and peat. The taste was a little less complicated. Solid dark chocolate, spices, peat, light coffee, and dark fruits. Medium body, some carbonation. Finish was spices and peat. Good, not my fav however.

On tap at the brewpub, served in an English pint. Pours hazy chestnut with a moderate creamy tan head that fades slowly to a thin cover. The nose has big chocolate and roast malts, along with prominent hops, brown sugar and a touch of coffee. The flavour is balanced between slightly dry malts with dark chocolate on the one hand and roasted malts, coffee and earth on the other. The finish is long and roasty with lingering chocolate and complex hops. On the palate it is medium-full in body with a milky texture an average carbonation. Overall a very nice chocolate porter with impressive American hops. 2013-12-29

Poured from bottle to glass. Dark black with off white head. Aroma is coffee, pine, caramel, figs, roasted malt, citrus. Mouthfeel is great with a medium light body and average carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with a bitter & astringent following and a dry finish. Overall this is a complex brew that marries a Porter with an IPA. Very well done.
I thought that the citrusy hops clashed with the roasty porter characteristics. im disappointed; ive loved a lot of hoppy porters, but apparently not this one

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2014 Bottle (2012), with thanks to Drew. Pours a deep ruby black with a medium brown head, creamy with nice lacing. Aroma is roasty, cigarettes, chocolate, rich. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet, roasty, coffee, chocolate, touch of ashes, medium bitterness. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Things really come together nicely in this beer. Not getting much individual character from whatever "strange" hops were used due to the age, but what this has become is downright awesome. Definitely one of my favorite imperial porters.

Pours nearly pitch black with a little light on the edges and a fluffy brown head. Nice roasty malt on the aroma, milk chocolate, caramel, nice floral hops, and something I assume is the mexican sugar. Super toasty taste, toffee, strange brown sugar note, caramel, and a nice citrusy hop finish. Not bad, the sugar adds a really strange taste. The strong hop character is really well balanced.

From a 22oz bottle, poured very dark brown medium head. Smell malty, slight chocolate with some hops. Taste some chocolate, licorice, hops slight vanilla. A very different type of porter but in a good way. Liked it a lot.

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks dude! pours very dark brown with a creamy light beige head, some retention and lacing. dense chocolate, coffee beans, pine and resin, minty and otehr green freshness, maple, spices, some sweetness - demerara and treacle, hint of lactose. moderate carbonation, light to medium body - oily, assertive grassy-spicy-piney finish. balanced robust porter. very nice concoction. much enjoyed!

Bottle 22oz.
Pours black with low-medium head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, mint. Taste is of chocolate, dust, roasted malt, some "fresh" feeling. Palate: Light-medium body. Overall: Nice roastiness. Kind of black IPAish. A good beer.

Bottle (22 oz). From Randall, thanks! Dark brown with a medium beige head and some lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, minty nores, vanilla, light vegetal notes, chocolate and liquorice notes. Taste is slightly sweet with minty notes, vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and herbal finish. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Silky mouthfeel. Good balance. Nice Porter, but also almost a Black IPA. Tasty.
On draft at Twenty Tap in Indianapolis. Pours black with a tan head. Roasty malt nose. Flavors of chocolate and licorice. Medium bodied. Light carbonation. Lingering bitter finish.

Pitch Black Color, Huge Foamy Head That Lasts Forever and Leaves Decent Lacing. Nice Fruity Hop Aroma, Reminds Me of Passion Fruit. Unexpected Since Porters Dont Smell Like It. I Guess This Is Part of that "Its Not Normal" Slogan That is Printed On Its Label. Taste of Toasted Malt, Faint Chocolate that barely Shines through Strong Floral Hop Bitter. Medium Body. Hides ABV Real Well. Not Your Classic Porter For Sure. Interesting. Enjoyed It. Recommended...

Pours a dark brown with a small offwhite head that offers good lacing. Aroma is of minty hops and spices, feeling fresh and light. Taste is sweet, full of spices, chocolate and roasted malt. Body was medium, maybe a bit on the light side. This isnt your typical porter but it has a good american character (just enough so it doesnt become a black IPA) to it and is really just fun to drink. Nice!

Want to know how to balance the rich, dark flavors of chocolate malt w/ American hops? Look know further than this beauty. One of most balanced beers Ive ever tasted with every flavor working together, yet standing out on its own. I could drink this all day.

Very dark brown pour with a good amount of light brown head. Very hoppy aroma mixed with malt and a hint of chocolate/vanilla. The hop character is very present right away, but the finish is where you get that porter maltyness and bitterness. Good brew
Draft.Black tan head. Chocolate and coffee nose. Coco, light hop and very faint coffee. Love this one

On tap at FFF brewpub poured into a half pint. Appearance is very dark brown with little light coming through. A stiff tan head stands an inch over the beer. It clings tightly to the glass in patches as the session goes on and Finding Nemo flashes on the screens in the pub. Aroma is pine, cocoa, roasted malt, and the slightest bit of orange peel. Quite hoppy for a porter. Taste is initially bitter with spruce and anise. Then the essence of one of those chocolate-wrapped oranges from Christmastime slides in. Roasty and charred notes on the swallow. Medium body, creamy, but thinner than it looks, moderate carbonation, semi-dry finish.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with brown head. Nose and taste of citrus, roast chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, coffee and candy cane. Medium body. Slightly dry/roasty finish.
Deep dark colored porter. Lots of roasted malt followed by coffee and faint chocolate. Hops are definitely present and add nice citrus notes. Nice smooth finish

On tap at three floyds. Pours a dark, almost stoutlike black. Aroma is big coffee and chocolate malts. Sweet aroma. Taste is smooth. Good flavor, with roasted coffee notes and hints of chocolate. Sweet, but not overly sweet. Almost stoutlike. Thin on the palate, not thick or creamy at all. Pretty good beer.
Heavy roasted coffee notes. Needed. To warm up to get the full aroma. Aroma is still toasty with coffee. Body was full overall a good beer but not awesome. Have a bottle and will reevaluate later.
Bottle pour opaque black thick tan head. Nose grassy and floral hop with some chocolate. Taste roast, coffee, lots of flavoring hop as well. Pine and floral. Very hoppy porter, and I like it.

Dark brown almost black in color. 1 finger light brown head that dissipates quickly. Grassy nose with dry coffee taste. Has a slight sour finish. 2013 is more sour than I recall from 2012 but still great.

Bottle, thnx to Budznudz, Cheers! Pours a dark brown, almost black beer with a thin beige head on top. Aroma of coffee, roast, dark chocolate and licorice. Flavor is mildly sweet with big tones of coffee and chocolate. Very much licorice present in the aftertaste of the flavor. Medium dry finish. Not a typical Christmas beer, but still very nice to enjoy over Christmas dinner. Nice one.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2014 From a bottle. Pours black with a thin tan head. Very roasty chocolate and pine with some hops. Slightly bitter finish. Very good.

12 bottle. Very dark pour. Roasty aroma, nice hop charActer...hoppier than a regular porter but the year has died off some hops to make this smoother. Lightly roasty flavor as well, some coffee, hops are present. Overall good, hop forward porter.

Bottle from DrewFace... U da man. Pours blacksmith white head. Aroma is strong chocolate, with just mild hops. Bottle is 1 yr d, so thats good. Taste is chocolate, light, smooth, not too hoppy. Interested to see what this would be fresh.

Bottle, thanks to DrFabulous. Pours nearly black with creamy mocha head. Aroma - whoa thats a lot of pine/spruce. Was not expecting that. Also chocolate. Taste: piney, herbal hops dominate this. There is chocolate and roast, but this is close to a chocolatey black ipa. Lasting bitter finish, only slight sweetness. Palate: slick texture, medium body, average to lively carbonation. Overall: not at all what I expected. I guess this is a Christmas porter in the sense that it feels like drinking a Christmas tree thats been dusted with chocolate. Would probably categorize this as a black ipa personally.
Excellent porter! Had this at a Christmas tasting party. Thanks Doug for a great tasting!

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 22oz bomber poured into a snifter. This was the second bomber Ive had of this particular beer, the first one mustve been a dud - I didnt smell any strong aromas - but this time, the smell of Xmas spices came through strong at first (cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and anise?), although it gave way to a damp, basement-like smells. There is some light roasted nut smells in the background too, but the smell finally settles on a light spruce and floral smells. A very thick, creamy brown head forms and sticks around for awhile leaving an even blanket of lacing on the way down the glass. This sits atop a dark, opaque coffee color body. It mostly chocolate malt sweet with some very mild coffee bitter notes to it. Its light bodied, mostly flat (although there is some trace carbonation) with a creamy, but slick, feel to it. It finishes with a roasty coffee flavor coating the mouth. Accompanying the coffee aftertaste are notes of some chocolate malt, maybe some brown sugar to it and some citrus zest, as well as notes of the Xmas spices mentioned earlier in the aroma.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 23.12.2013, 0,65l bottle @ home:
Big slightly brown creamy longlasting head. Aroma is dark malts, lots of hops, coffee, licorice, rubber, dark sugar, chocolate. Taste is slightly dry, dark malts, hops, leafs, cocoa, licorice, coffee, rubber, hay. Longlasting mild bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Nice and balanced beer, even though I dont feel anything Christmasy in this one.
Bottle pours black with nice head. Aroma is chocolate and spicy hops. taste is rich roast with a smooth finish, great hop burps

Pours thick unclear dark coffee with a beige head. Aroma brings sprucey hops so fresh with some roasted malts. Flavor is really hoppy for a porter. Roasted creamy malts are under a prevalent hop profile.
not sure what made this one christmas-y, as i didnt really get any spices per se. but overall a decent porter anyway.

Bomber bottle, to glass. Very dark color with little head. A strong dark, porter/coffee nose, can also smell some alcohol in there. A strong coffee bitterness that lingers on the tongue. I didn't really notice the usual 3F hoppiness. Medium carbonation. A little bit of an alcohol finish in the back of the throat. I am not usually a porter drinker, but this is good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 Im not a big porter fan, but good ones are enjoyable, and this one is very good. Chocolate, dark roast coffee and a nice citrus bitterness. Very tasty and very drinkable.  Updated:  After trying many other porters in the ensuing year, Alpha Klaus seems a bit odd as a porter...maybe its the sugar or some sort of spices?

Santa would be a very jolly fellow after a pint of this! Wow! Draft in a small snifter from Fiddlers, our local Irish pub. Lots of rich chocolate and tar on the nose and the palate. The hops come through on the finish. I think this would be very good warm. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a 22oz bomber. Aroma is roasty chocolate and citrus. Flavors are chocolate, roasty malt, citrus, and slight pine. Very solid drinkable porter! So much better fresh!! 3 Floyds FTW!

On tap at Three Floyds. Black with thin brown head. Aroma is roasty with C-hops. Taste is creamy and roasty with chocolate and sharp C-hops. Bitter finish. Id call this more of a Black IPA. Delicious.

Bottle from Rebekah as part of an awesome FFF box. Thanks again! Pours nearly black with a super creamy two finger mocha colored head. Big hop aroma that I wasn't expecting. Pine galore, some lemon, some roast, chocolate, and big sweet sugar. Big chocolate and hop mixture in flavor. Lots of bitterness and pine, some sweet chocolate, then a bit of buttering roasted malts. Medium bodied, pretty smooth, with medium plus carbonation. Very drinkable. Dry finish. I was not expecting this at all, and for some reason was thinking this would be a big sweet chocolate dessert. I like it though, and it is a big hoppy porter bordering on black IPA. Glad I finally got my hands on this one.
Pours inky black with a thin tan head. Woody, hoppy aroma. Taste is very complex, chocolate, wood, oranges. Finish is bitter with orange and cocoa.
bottle. Big, beautiful Porter - perfect for a cold, snowy night. Easy to drink and robust flavor. Three Floyds makes great beer

Bottle from RobertDale. Thanks Bob!! Aroma has notes of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, piney and citrus hops. Black in the glass with an average off-white head that mostly diminished and left great lace. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter. Palate is full bodied and watery with an average carbonation. Overall a really nice brew thats quite drinkable.

On tap, black pour with a tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and coffee with subtle cocoa notes and lots of hops. Flavor is a bit of a mess, the roasted character of this beer doesnt mingle very well with the hop bill. Its like this beer cant decide what it wants to be. Drinkable but I wouldnt go back for seconds.

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasty/coffee, caramel and some pine. Taste has some pine and is roasty and well balanced with a grapefruity bitterness at the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is pine, coffee, light toffee and slight vinous notes. The flavor is dark malts, coffee, mild/medium grapefruit, hop resin, vinous notes and an acidic/tart/sour finish.

Love this porter from three floyds. Super bitter and chocolately with a bitter finish. Smells malty 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650ml Bottle from our local grocery store. Appearance is dark brown color with lots of creamy beige head. Aroma is heavy with roasted malts, vanilla and spice. Taste is similar but a bit more complex with roasted grains, dark chocolate dominant but strong notes of pine hops, allspice, and sugar. Palate is full-bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a semi-dry finish. A unique contribution to the Christmas ale pantheon.

Pour is close to black with a small tan head. Aroma is huge on the chocolate with notes of roasted pine nuts, toffee, and coffee. Flavor is more bitter/hoppy than the nose with added characteristics of licorice, smoke, spice, and caramel. Well balanced.
Floral nose and very hoppy for a porter. This is how all xmad beers should be made. Excellent!
Thanks wes. Tight stable brown head. Pretty dry palate. A very hoppy porter with citrusy cascade I think.

Bottle: pours a great dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is a nice mixture of citrus and sweet chocolate. Taste is roasty with chocolate, and a bright piney hop presence. Very well balanced and fun to drink. Nice!

Pour dark brown with khaki head that leaves a bit of lacing. Smells of coffee, chocolate and piney hops. Taste is strong roasted malt, cocoa and coffee with a bitter hop finish. Quite a tasty brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black pour with a 1 finger, creamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted nuts, light toffee, roast, vanilla crème, pie spice, and earthy, spicy and citrus hops. Flavor is loaded with chocolate and roast up front, caramel, woody vanilla, dry roasted nuts, a touch of spice, licorice, and a hint of smoke and char. Medium body creamy, slightly chewy entry, creamy middle and creamy, slightly dry finish with a light to medium, blanketing carbonation. Really freaking tasty nice, fairly hoppy porter that is awesome without needing a gimmick.
I love the hoppy aroma combined with the dark malts. Deep roasted malt flavors with some chocolate and coffee. Some really nice hop flavors combined to make a great porter. One of the best.

22oz bottle pours black with big pillowy tan head. Nose is coffee, cream, milk chocolate, a touch of evergreen, sweet notes. Taste is sweet milk chocolate and coffee with a hint of nuts and spices. Mouthfeel is slightly slick but smooth and creamy, well balanced. Finish is rich dark cocao and coffee, some pine notes, sweet. Delicious.

Pours pitch black with a thin very thin cap of chocolatey head that dissipates quick. Not much carbonation. Nose is very sweet.
Very chocolatey with a lot of dark fruits, mainly cherries,
Plum and grape. A very good malt backbone is present with a slight roastiness to it. Mouth is very creamy a lot of roast and chocolate with dark fruits again present. A good mix of caramel, hops and malt. The hops are actually strong on the finish. Nice bitterness.

Another overpriced offering by the greedy brothers at three floyds.

Pours like a milk stout. Dark foam. Black bodied. 

Lacking down a quarter of my pint glass.

Off the nose sweet milk. Minimal chocolate, sugar and of course sweet hopps. Very average but hoppy porter.

Should be offered in 6 pack for $9.99.

A 22 oz for $9.99 is insulting in my opinion.

It's not that great. A little below average in my opinion.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, thanks to lumpsowers, 11/14/2013. Pours black, frothy light tan head dies to a splotchy haze, thick ring of lacing left behind. Aroma is big, nutty chocolate malts, cinnamon and pepper coming through the middle, strange Mexican candy, finish heavy with citrus hops. Taste is dark chocolate, coffee roast, big citrus hop presence, slight pine character adding to bitter finish, subtle pepper. Medium body, smooth. Solid.
At FFF. Poured brown black with light rim of cream. Very light aroma of hop choc. Quite smooth with balanced hop bitterness.

A: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Mild Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

S: Dark Chocolate Malts, Mild Cinnamon

T: Chocolate Malts, Mild Cinnamon, Mild Chili Peppers

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Spicy, Mildly Bitter

Overall, a pretty nice pepper, spicy porter...wont kill you but a whole bomber will cause AIDS and heart burn.

22oz bottle thanks to AndyReynolds - pours soopa dark brown with little head of some color. Nose is coffee. Sweet with roasted and hoppy bitterness. Tasty after a weekend of American lagers. Pine and resin aftertaste.
22oz bomber. Pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, rosary, vanilla, and spice. Tastes of chocolate, roast, and sweet malts, with a nice hoppy bitter finish.

Murky dark brown to black
Cinnamon and some maple notes on the nose. Holiday spices all the way 
Spicy tobacco taste. Sweet finish. Pretty burnt. Hints of chocolate

22 oz. bottle thanks to queenholly, shared with friends. Yes we are drinking a X-mas porter in June! Nose is a really great cinnamon, chocolate and earthy pine. The base of the beer is burnt grain, with nice notes of chocolate, earthy dead leaves and a bit of char. The texture is real dry. The body is a perfect medium with some dead pine notes in the finish. The more I sip it the more I enjoy this. Real nice brew.

Bottle. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Aroma is piney and citrusy hops backed up by roasty chocolate malt. Taste is very much the same, perhaps with a touch of menthol and coffee. Palate is full with a sharp carb. Very unique and very awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber.  Nice dark heavy pour with off white head and a bit of retention.  Nose is all kinds of chocolate, coco, roast and vanilla.  Taste follows the nose with some residual hop bitterness and sugar.  Well done.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 15, 2017 Another really nice beer from Three Floyds. Very aggressive.  I expected a bit more on the spice side, but what this really was was a very well-hopped porter.  
Tried it again in 2017 courtesy of Scott and Andy.
Bottle. Pours very dark. Tons of spice on the nose, still not a fan of the Christmas beers but this is better than most.

Bottle at the in-laws. Pour is pitch black with a frothy brown head and goo lacing. Big roast, dark chocolate, light nutmeg, vanilla, toasted bread, dark fruit, and oaky aroma. Taste is big dark chocolate, coffee, light vanilla, woody, lightly spicy, sweet vanilla, and grassy with a lightly bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel with medium-to-soft carbonation. Nice porter, but I would have really loved a thicker mouthfeel
Bomber, pours a solid black with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate malt and hops.  Taste is roasted chocolate and coffee balanced out nicely with some bitter hops.  Solid porter.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2013 Pours an opaque black color with a caramelized creme brûlée colored foamy head. The head forms quickly and largely. Some semblance of head lingers throughout the beer. Lacing and spider webbing coat the glass from top to bottom. Late summer mown grass, coffee, and roastiness on the nose. Moutfheel is thick and slick, but dries out a little at the finish. Perfectly balanced roasted malt and resinous hops. It fills the mouth with flavor. Grassy hop flavor blending well with large roasted malt. This is a magnificent beer with a lot of balance. Ive missed it so much.
Pours dark brown/black with a tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, malty aroma.  Flavor is chocolate, malt, pine, coffee, roasty.

22 ounce bottle into signature Teku tulip; November 2012 release.  Pours pitch black color with a 2 finger fairly dense dark tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice soapy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big dark chocolate, roasted malt, grapefruit, pine, orange zest, floral, cocoa, caramel, coffee, light char, and piney spiciness.  Fantastic aromas with great balance of hop and dark roasted malt notes.  Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malt, grapefruit, pine, floral, char, coffee, caramel, and roasted earthiness.  Good amount of roasted pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, roasted malt, pine, citrus, floral, char, coffee, caramel, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic balance and complexity of very dark malty flavors with citrus/pine hops; with a great malt/bitterness balance; and zero cloying flavors present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a very creamy, sticky, fairly crisp, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with almost zero warming noticed after the finish.  I know this is labeled as a porter; but in my view, this is an absolutely fantastic Black IPA!  Big balance and complexity of dark malt and citrus/pine hop flavors; and extremely smooth to sip on.  An extremely awesome offering!
Poured from a large format bottle. Pours with a dense head and coffee. The flavor is of coffee, chocolate, fruity yeast and hops.  Very tasty almost like an iced coffee.

Poured from bomber - pretty much black pour with an intense tan head.  Aroma is pleasant, nice mixture of sweet malt and bitter hops...some chocolate, slight burnt note...good stuff.  Flavor is a bit more hoppy than I anticipated (though it is FFF, so I shouldnt be that surprised)...lots of sweet and roasted malt accents, some bitter chocolate...again, good flavor.  Palate is average for the style.  Good beer that I would definitely enjoy again down the road.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 I love this beer!! 22oz bomber. Pours a deep brownish almost black color with nice 2 fingers of creamy off white head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, and pine. Taste is amazing! Pretty much a black ipa. Roasted malt, chocolate, slight coffee, with a nice bitter hop bite! One of my favorites!

Acquired in a trade from jaminjohnson.  It poured a dark brown/black color with a medium to heavy creamy body.  The aroma was of toasted malt, chocolate, cocoa and plenty of hops. The taste was of roasted sweet malt, milk chocolate, hops, coffee, some vanilla and light caramel. A very good porter.
Bomber from brewpub pours dark black with a big tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Great porter roasted malt Carmel with big hop flavor.
bottle. black pour. great porter, chocolate & heavy roastiness. fuller bodied. big dose of bitterness. full mouthfeel. really nice porter

Bottle from trade with kmyers8807, thanks!
Dark brown to black with a beige brown head.
Aroma: roasted and creamy, light spices, milk chocolate, some citrus.
Taste: roasted, fruity, (light burnt) rubber, some spices, light licorice, hoppy with mostly citrus fruits and a hint of tropical, but not bitter.
Medium bodied, smooth.
Very nice.

Dark brown pour into a tulip with a lively tan head with tons of carbonation. The aroma is pinecone hops and roasted malt. As far as the taste goes, this is a straight up black ipa, but the chocolate notes come out as it warms.  Roasted malt paired with fresh hops make up the taste which is not very complex but is well done for what it is. Thin to medium body, medium smoothness on the palate. Great for a black ipa, but I was expecting a porter.

Location: 22 oz bottle, 2/3/13, First beer of Super Bowl Day 2013!


Aroma: The nose has some sweet hops, citrus, pine, along with dark malts, coffee, and spice

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a small beige head that leaves plenty of drippy lace

Flavor: The malts come out more in the early flavor then they did in the nose, with chocolate and roasted coffee up-front to go along with the plentiful and lingering hop bitterness that shows up later on 

Palate: The body is medium, it has a smooth mouthfeel, soft carbonation, and a dry finish

Overall Impression: 
Thanks to whatever combination from the Nerd Beer Epic Weekend crew for hooking me up with this one!  This is a top notch Porter for sure, and another great beer from Three Floyds.

Via gtrade with Nasty31.  The aroma is hops upfront, earthy, spicy, bitter chocolate.  The appearance is jet black,  tan head.  The flavor is hoppy, earthy, spicy, chocolate, candi sugar, sweet.  The finish is a hop explosion, bitter pine needles, flowers, earth.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Interesting, enjoyable, and a bit odd.  Thanks, Andrew,

On tap at 3F---just a half pint, but oh so lovely.  Dark, pure black color with a large, tan head.  Aroma was chocolatey and citrusy with a touch of coffee.  Chocolate taste with a citrus nip and smooth mouthfeel, sweeter than an average porter.  Bitter finish.

Dark brown with good head and lacing. Chocolate roasty and piney hop aroma with molasses.  Mild sweetness with roasty and mild grassy hop taste.   Chocolate mid taste and semi bitter finish.  Moderate mouthfeel that is semi highly carbonated.  Good combination of a porter and an IPA.  Dry.   I would drink again but probably wouldn't buy.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle to snifter.  Pours dark brown with light tan head.  Smell is hops with light chocolate.  Taste is the same with some coffee.  Hops taste is hard to nail down.  Stops short of a piney taste.  More hoppy than a typical porter.  Somewhat dry.  Okay.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber thanks to queenholly, aroma of coffee, chocolate, nice hop level, and nuts, like penisbutter, dammit Matt, I mean peanut butter. Taste has a well rounded hoppiness with chocolate, slight coffee, more hops on the finish. A nice hoppy porter.

Dark brown no head. Hoppy brown sugar molasses chocolate smell. Carbonated hop bite at first that gives way to a chocolate and molasses then the hops come back at the end. Definitely feels like a combo of porter and IPA. Pretty good, I like the balance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great mouthfeel -- thick but not syrupy. The base maltiness is surprisingly complex, even spicy, which may be due to the hops that so not impart much bitterness. The chocolate flavor is subdued in a good way, providing an extra layer of flavor without bogging down the beer so that it becomes a candy bar. What lingers is an earthy malt flavor imbued with chocolate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dry porter yeast meets an unenthusiastic malt blend and nonexistent spices. Unfortunately, this 2012 version is nothing special at all; last year's was significantly better. "This is a beer. It tastes like beer."

Bottle thanks to Jstax ! Pours a deep burnt umber color with a three finger mocha foam that laces and sticks nicely. On the nose its some burnt chocolate, spent coffee grounds and a touch of resinous pine and citrus. The palate is round and has great mouthfeel with roasty malts mingling with  dank resinous hop notes on the mid to late palate. Tasty.

Very tasty. Not a porter fan, but this could change my mind.                      

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at 3F's. black pour into half imperial pint. Head is tan and a quarter inch, fair amount of lacing as well. Aroma of chocolate and tart citrus hops. Mouth feel is thin, slightly foamy. Rich sweet taste. Flavors of sweet but roasty chocolate and piney hops. Finish is more roastiness, bitter and dry. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours very dark brown with a small beige head that fades quickly.  Big lacing and webbing on the glass.  Interesting aroma, some things I dont regonize here but it smells good.  Definitely milk chocolate, roasted coffee, flowers, and some spices I guess.  Taste is unique for sure.  Sweeter than I usually like in a porter but it works here with the hops and spices.  Slightly roasted and chocolaty but I taste mostly floral hops and spices.  Medium body and creamy mouthfeel.  Not my favorite porter but still really good,  Glad I finally tried this.
22 ounce bottle.  Thanks Joe!  Pours almost black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and florals.  Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, spice, and hops.  Yummy!!

On Tap. Pours black with brown head. Aroma of chocolate and malts. Taste the chocolate and roasted malts you would expect from a Porter but the Hops make this a TREAT!

----Hophaze out

Bomber poured into HF stemware

Poured pitch black, smell and taste of chocolate porter,, burnt sugar.  Incredible balance and slight hoppiness.  Very delicious

Bottle from my secret Santa. Pours pitch black with a huge frothy tanned head. Aroma is roasted malts, liquorice , dark chocolate and pine. Taste is dry and bitter, mellow and velvety mouthfeel, lots of liquorice and cocoa, roasted malts, lingering dry piney hops. Very good one indeed.

December 25, 2012 bottle but cant remember where from. Dark brown pour with nice head that lasted and lacing. Chocolate, roasted malt and spice in aroma. Taste was consistent with aroma and mild dry bitter finish. Medium body and slight carbonation.
Dark. Tan head with heavy lacing. Aroma full of coffee chocolate and hops.Full body but not chewy. Creamy. Flavor is roasty, chocolate, and some coffee followed by distinguishable hop bite.

From a trade with olr1984.  Cheers man!  Opaque brown with some lacing but minimal head.  Nose of dark roast chocolaty malts and floral hops.  Taste is roast malt, bitter hops, and then dark roasty coffee finish.  Some mexican spice like piloncillo aftertaste.  Full bodied.  Terrific porter.

On tap at Fiddlers Hearth in South Bend. Served in a nonic pint.

Pour: Nearly pitch black body, with a thick, two fingers deep khaki head. Head sticks around for most of the glass, and leaves really nice lacing the entire way.

Smell: Roasted malts up front, with some tobacco. A floral hoppiness comes in and completely hijacks the whole affair. Finish is a mix of hops and roasted coffee.

Taste: Roasted malts hit first again, but then dance with a bitter hop floral and grassy flavors. Some light dark chocolate bitterness. Finishes roasty and bitter.

Mouthfeel: Quite light and drinkable. Amongst the best drinking porters Ive ever had to be honest.

Overall: This beer blurs the line between a black IPA and a porter. I actually really enjoy it, and the hoppyness is exactly what I should have expected from Three Floyds.
Bottle shared in Vail. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a deep brown color with off white head. Fresh piney, hoppy, roasty flavors. Tastes like a black IPA.

Bottle in Vail, courtesy of Thealum. Thanks Adam! Pours a black appearance with a light brown head. Piney, somewhat bitter hoppy, roasty dark chocolate malty, coffee, a bit herbal aroma. Creamy dark chocolate malty, minty/piney, a bit herbal spicy, roasty coffee flavor. Tasty, full flavored and easy to drink.

Dark brown body with with tan head. Aroma tropical fruit 3 Floyd signature style. Taste Mexican sugar spice, semi sweet chocolate, good rosted notes with bitter finish. Mouthfeel milky. Kick butt porter second to snow weasel IMO.

22 oz bomber into a FFF .5L glass. 

A - Pours a black that exposes some dark brown tints around the corners of the glass. Nice and fluffy khaki three finger head forms, settles into a thin but lasting cap. Great lacing and retention. Super sticky and clinging.

S - The aroma starts off with sweet milk chocolate, burnt coffee, and roasted malts. A huge blast of piney and grapefruit hops then sends you into confusion. 

T - Sweet bakers chocolate, espresso, and char collide with the piney and citric hops. The flavors wash away quickly leaving behind the bitterness typical of an IPA.

M - On the thin to medium side with plenty of carbonation. Works well with the style and flavors and makes for an easy drinking beer. In the span of this review Ive already downed a glass...

O - Apparently a porter really works well when its hopped up. Light enough to be drinkable with plenty of chocolaty coffee goodness to balance out that distinctive FFF hop profile.

This pours a very dark brown color with a fluffy light brown head. There is a mild scent of roasted malts to the beer but even stronger is the scent of hops. The taste is uniquely robust yet hoppy. Initially there is a complex, robust sweetness which gradually grows into a crisp, bitter taste. Very different and very 3 Floyds! Leaves a decent clinging lacing.

Bottle.  Piney grapefruit hops aroma. chocolate malt, light coffee aroma. Black with a large tan head, thick sticky lacing. Coffee, tart dark fruit, chocolate, piney grapefruit hops, and lightly acidic flavor. Full, slightly astringent body, moderate carbonation
Pretty great beer- had in a great bomber style bottle. More hops than malt, and its definitely related to the infamous Alpha King from 3T. The character in strong in this one, gang.

Definitive scent of spices, roasted malts, chocoate, and hops. The flavor is good. The prime flavors are delicious sweet roasted malts and hops. Secondary flavors are chocolate and minor notes of spice. Overall this is a very above average porter.

Deep brown / black with hints of red on the edges. Large tan head and excellent lacing on the glass. Immediately struck by the roasted burnt notes and apparent hops on the nose. Bitterness throughout with hints of tobacco and roasted coffee.

Pours a Carl brown black color with a large mocha head. Nose is malty, chocolate and dark espresso. Taste is bitter and sweet with coffee and chocolate notes. Nice complex mix with nicely balanced hops and malt. Finish is bitter sweet, expect nothing less from 3Fs. Quaff Score 9 / 10

Pours a dark brown with a brown head and aroma of hops and roasted malt. Taste is bitter, of hops, sweet chocolate malt, and caramel with a bitter, long, hoppy finish. Very tasty, drinkable, delicious beer, another gem from Three Floyds
True to 3 Floyds style a hoppy porter that has a piney nose and a wonderful dry chocolate and coffee taste with a subtle hop note.  Fun, unique porter.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2016 22oz bottle. Nose is earthy hops and tobacco. Pours a dark brown / red but not completely opaque near-black color, with a good light brown head, that leaves nice rows of lace. Big earthy piney hop flavor, tobacco, smoked and toasted malts. Some roasty espresso flavors.... Surprisingly big, complex flavor, here. Lighter body, for the ABV. Very dry texture. Very light carbonation. Good bittersweet aftertaste. The aroma in this is very nice, exactly what I want in a hoppy porter. Brings to mind Mikkellers Beer Hop Breakfast, even. But something about this leaves something to be desired, still. Could be the thinnish body or excessively dry texture. I expected a hoppy porter, but this is an extremely hoppy porter. Good stuff, but maybe a little more balance would be cool 8/4/7/3/15 Update rate, 2/26/16: 22oz bottle, split 3 ways. Thanks to robotopera for sharing. Dated 11/11/15. Bigger roast malt up front. Some dark chocolate. Bigger piney peppery hop. Assertive bigger bitterness, moderate sweet. Hazy dark brown / red color. Thin light brown head. Loose bits of lace. Medium to bigger body. Kind of slick texture, mildly chewy. Lighter, crisp carbonation. Nice earthy hop, chocolate, nuttiness in the finish. Mildly leathery. Seeing some of the smoke and tobacco again. Tasty hoppy porter. Probably even better nearer to Christmas. Old scored kept the same. 7/4/7/4/15

Bomber to snifter (shared with the Mrs.).  Looks good; black with foamy beige head.  Smells good too; hoppy and malty with notes of chocolate.  Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel.  Damn tasty!
bomber thanks kan! pours black with medium tan head. big pine citrus and roast grain aroma. taste is slight sweet loads of hops and chocolate

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 Pours a jet black color with a two finger creamy head that goes away slowly. Smells of citrus fruits like pineapple and lemon with some pine; as well as roasted coffee and chocolate undertones. Can detect some sweetness from the mexican sugar as well. Smells more like a black ipa than a porter, but Im not surprised because it is floyds. The taste profile is the opposite of the smell. Taste starts with roasted coffee, some milk chocolate, vanilla. Then in the middle you start to get the citrus fruits like lemon and grapefruit. But mostly get pine qualities which make sense since it is a christmas porter. Gets a much smoother and creamier mouthfeel. The roasted coffee and chocolate stay constant throughout. Finishes with a blend of the pine and citrus qualities, as well as the bold, roasted coffee and chocolate notes, maybe some licorice. For a 6% beer, the mouthfeel is not watery in the least bit. Medium body with a creamy and sticky mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. Not as good as their snow weasel porter, which has more hop qualities in it; but still a top notch, smooth porter.
Black pour from a bomber at witts.  Tons of tan sticky head. Rich coffe stout taste.  Creamy milky coffee taster.   Awesome

Pours a ashy black with a tan head that sticks around a bit. Aromas of cigarettes, ash trays and canihave4beers man purses. Wow. Nice and hoppy, refined, thick like the business end of a black mamba. Good.

pours very dark in the glass, aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, molasses and piney hops. taste is very roasty with some coffee notes and hoppy in an ipa sense with bitterness on the finish. this is a very good porter with a nice twist on the style and probably the best porter I have had or atleast the best that I like.

Black...with an oily, dark tan head.
Scent is sweet, roast chocolate....hop tones.
Flavour is sugared coffee, darkly roasted.
Creamy chocolate over a smoky-sweet coffee bitter.
This....is quite simply.....Superb.
An absolutely wonderful porter.
3F....thats about all that needs said.

This is what a porter should be like. Pours beautifully with a thick tan head that persists leaving a thick lace.  The aroma of candied floral hops are stongly apparent as I take a sip.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel with chocolate malts coming through nicely.  Residual sweetness balances the resiny hop finish nicely. Flavors of mocha honey and pine come together harmoniously to make one alphalicious porter.
Pours black with tan head.  Aroma of hops and some malts with spice.  Taste is unique with a complex combo of chocolate, malts, spices and balanced with hops.  Wow.

Pours black with a tan head.  Smells of chocolaty hops, almost mint dark chocolate.  The taste is similar, very chocolaty but also very clean and crisp. It has a dry finish. The hops are just enough to add a nice bit of tang to the rich chocolate base.  I thought it was going to be a lot like a black IPA, which is a style I dont care for, but this tasted like a piny, minty chocolate.  Great beer.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.  Poured a lovely dark mahogany with a big frothy tan head. The aroma is malty but surprisingly weak. The flavour is bitter malt and liqourice. A really awesome rich flavourful ale.

Bottle shared.  Pours almost black with a small tan head.  Aroma of hops, malt, dough, chocolate, roasted malt, pine.  Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

66.cl bottle thanks to and shared with Kermis.
Hoppy aroma.  thin creamy tan head.  Clear black pour.  Hoppy  chocolate taste.  Lovely brew

As a former Porter aficionado now more into the hoppy stuff, holy cow this is enough to make me question my direction in beerhood.

Awesome, very tasty balance of all the classic things you want in a Porter, but with a nice juicy, tart hop profile layered over it.

This might not be what I want to drink every day, but when I want a porter, Im going to think of this (and, since its 3Fs, most likely then lament that I cant find another bottle of it, ye bastards)

Pours very black with a good tan head.  The aroma contains roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and some mint, which is kind of unusual.  The taste gives quite a different impression.  Lots of pine and hops in here which makes it feel like a Three Floyds beer.  I still get a good amount of mint, with the malty impressions being undertones but coming through more at the end.  Aftertaste is roasty, with mint and coffee, and lasts awhile.  Full bodied with a thick, yet slick, mouthful.  Slightly bitter at the end as well.  Pretty good I must say.  But there are others from Three Floyds that I would rather drink.

Bomber, 2012. Drank this one a few times over the years but didnt rate it for some reason, this year though it wasnt as good as I recall from previous years... but that may just be my palate, not the beer itself. Nice, opaque brown-black pour, with immense chestnut colored head, excellent retention. Roasty and some hops in the nose, but mostly roasted malt and coffee notes, with some hint of brown sugar in the mouth. Ive been drinking a lot of porters/stouts lately, and this one wasnt as remarkable as others Ive had lately. Still, not bad though. To quote C. Griswold: Merry Christmas... Merry Christmas... Kiss my ass... Kiss his ass... Happy Chanukah. ;-)

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Fresh bottle appropriately served in a three floyds pint glass. Pours a dark brown/black with a inch thick tan head. It leaves great lacing. Aroma is strong, I can smell it from a foot away. Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, pine, some disguised citrus, and hints of cream. Taste is malts, chocolate, oranges, grapefruit, sweet cream, and sugar. The sugar actually lingers on the tongue and lips nicely. It has the trademark three floyds hop flavor.  Mouthfeel is medium and easy to drink. This is an amazing porter.

22 oz. bottle, pours jet black with a small tan head. Aroma of English malts, toasted biscuits, some winter light spices and caramelized brown sugar. Flavour is very darkly roasted, with English chocolate malt, dark caramelized sugar, and some burnt notes - some hops still plowing their way through after almost a year. Very full-bodied, burnt and roasty. Good stuff.

@ Publican in Chicago-- thick near black with a messy tan head. Strikingly hoppy aroma with minty juniper traits, underlying sweet dark malts. Hearty full bodied dark malt structure, chocolate, ash, beef broth, with equally dominant hop character that leans more toward coniferous and herbal traits. A different profile than most imperial porters, but in a very good way (why expect otherwise from Three Floyds I guess!). Just awesome.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Chocolatey hops flavor. Very hoppy for a porter. Spices also make for very nice aroma.

Truly unique porter.  Hop forward is an understatement - dank citrus hop alpha king hop character super imposed over heavily roasted coffee beans and slighter dark fruits. This is classic FFF in and out 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had one of these on tap at Three Floyds. To me seemed a little like an India Brown Ale since I detected more hops than expected from a porter.  dark brown, lightly bitter, medium body.

Bottle from trade with Bobertkuekn. Black pour, fairly low head, and aroma of sweet roasted malt. Taste is roasted and sweet malt and some hop bitterness. Flavor is pronounced, from start to finish, with nice lingering flavors in the finish. Tends just slightly on the sweet side, but its good.
A super tasty, roasty treat. Dark pour with tan head, nice lacing. Nice mouthfeel, taste is a fantastic balance of toasted malts, sweetness from the sugars and hops. Really well done!

Damn ipad reloading pages!! Lots of chocolate and slight burnt in the nose. Body is light, residual sweetness and of bit of spice. Not much hops in the aroma but resinous finish. Easy drinker with a good bit of complexity.

"2008 bottling consumed Dec 18, 2009
This is actually the first time I have had this beer, and its from a bottle that has been in my cellar for a year.
Nice thick brown head atop a rich, dark beer. Aromas of chocolate, hops, roasted malt, toffee. A fabulous tasting brew, and easily one of the best porters I have had. This beer is really easy to drink, and I will definitely be picking up a few of these from FFF in a couple of days."

65cl, no mention of ABV, American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex Porter, roasted/bitter and slightly smoked/fruity, not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good X-Mas brew, yet expensive!

Rich dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, & hops; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, milk chocolate, hops, coffee, some vanilla, and caramel; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very tasty porter.

Bottle, thanks to Tom. Poured a dark purpleish black. Aromas of framboise raspberry, piney christmas trees, perfume, and cocoa. Taste is a chocolate cake with some raspeberry drizzle. Notes of cinnamon, sugar, dark fruits, coffee, roasty malts, vanilla.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2013 Perfect thick tan head atop a beautiful brown body. Nice even carbonation. Hoppy chocolate aroma. Those hops are fresh right now for sure. Flavor is rich with chocolate. Nice hop flavor with a light bitterness. Hop flavor and roasty maltiness lingers. Thick and chewy mouth feel. Extremely drinkable and satisfying. That thick head really has staying power, and forms a nice lacing on the glass. the balance in the flavors is perfect in this one. A must have while fresh.

Bottle of the most recent vintage (I think) shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours dark opaque black with a thin ring of light tan head. Nose is lightly roasty, nutty, with a bit of ash, some dark fruit, and some light herbal hops. Smooth nuttiness in the taste, with some charcoal. Pretty roasty, and not much hoppiness, and Id have guessed this was a pretty standard roasty stout or porter had I drank this blind.

From bomber. Pours a dark ass brown/ black, opaque colour with a tan head that dies down to a thin layer with splashes of lacing all over the place. Smells of chocolate and booze, and hops. Tastes of chocolate, coffee, a little dark chocolate bitter, tiny bit of hop and chalky. Not bad, would like to try on draught.

Poured into a New Belgium snifter. It poured smoothly and had a quickly dissipating khaki head, lacing the glass. It looked as if it were the prototype for a porter. The smell was excellent. It was rich, malty, roasted, and had a sweet fruit aroma as well, perhaps cranberry. It had great flavor. The flavor mimicked the aromas. It was spot on. It had a great consistency and was incredibly smooth. Its one of the most drinkable beers Ive had, and my list is extensive. The only knock on this beer is that it only comes in 22oz bombers. This one is a masterpiece.

Black color, nice carbonation, nice creamy tan head which lasts for quite awhile, very nice sticky lacing throughout the drink. The nose is of slight sweet malts, slight vanilla, and coffee/caramel. The taste follows the nose pretty much, their is a nice bitter finish. Medium body.

Pours a nice black with thin dark tan head, decent lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, caramel, vanilla, and a nice citrus hops.  Flavor matches well and comes together very nicely.  What a great brew!  Its also nice to not be disappointed with a 3F brew.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/17/2011.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Alpha Klaus pours a very dark brown color with a speck of ruby, with a fuller spectrum of cherry red colors in the edges of the glass. A fluffy, creamy beige head forms on the pour and lingers for a while, leaving lacing to cling to the glass.

There is chocolate malt, lots of pine hops and some light earthy and grassy hops in the aroma. 

This is sort of a simple porter. It starts off with some chocolate malt, but the pine hops are the focus. Some earthy and grassy hops are present as well, mimicking the aroma. Lingering hop bitterness. It seems like I do not agree with their recipe, but as usual, the execution was skillful. 

The body is moderately full, with medium creamy carbonation. The hops pull at my taste buds a little bit and leave the tongue dry, with some residue behind my lips. 

Heavily hopping this beer just was not a decision that coalesces with what I am looking for in a Christmas Porter. This is quite possibly the first time I will want a less-hopped beer and most likely the last.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Absolutely gorgeous.  Pours the blackest black with a small tan head.  Smells roasty and chocolatey.  Tastes a bit chocolately a little more thin on the palate than I would like.  Overall another very good FFF brew.
UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 Houblons macerés dans un percolateur rempli du meilleur café noir. Présence en bouche superbe avec un fini sec chocolaté.
Bottle shared with Timfoolery. Hops seem to be the repeating pattern in 3Fs brews. Just like the description says, tasted of chocolate with some bitter hoppiness. Solid brew.
Aroma of roast is overwhelming. This beer looks great in a glass. Lots of lacing and a nice big head. The hops really mellow the sweetness. Id drink this again.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black with thinner tan head and good lacing.  Smell is initially big roast, dark cocoa nibs and resinous bitter hops.  Taste is starts and ends with the hops, but the sugars, dark malts and chocolate swirl around.  Very nice and big hoppiness, but doesnt get to the Black IPA side of the spectrum.  Still holds the nice malt profile.  Lovely again Three Floyds.

Bottle.  Pour a motor oil black.  Big light brown head with strong lacing.  Strong hoppy aroma.  Flavors of dark chocolate and coffee.  Medium to strong palate.  Bitter mouthfeel.  Excellent beer.  Its like the best of both worlds between a porter and an IPA .  Just wish I could find this and other 3 Floyds in MI.

Bobmer into sniffer.pitch black think tan head that quickly dissapates.  Aroma is very bitter hop heavy with a touch of sweet malt.  You can taste a lot of hops in this.  Because of the hops it tastes more like a Black IPA than a porter.  Finishes dry.

i did try this when it was fresh about 6 weeks ago.  I think it is slightly better now.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with small dark brown highlights and thin medium brown head that dissapates quickly.  A little lacing, thick body, low carbonation, and hop aroma.  Taste is burnt chocolate malt and long bitter hops.  Good beer, alcohol pretty well covered, but I prefer Flying Dog Gonzo Imperial Porter for the style.
[place holder rating- notes backlog] 2011 edition. Very unimpressed. Chalky, astringent, very muted spice character. Stinging, weak palate. Did not enjoy this at all.

pours oil brown, cinnamon, milky head. spice, chocolate, pine spearmint on nose. roasted malts, coffee, cocoa, pine hops with an oily mouthfeel. medium bitterness. real drinkable, spicy heat on finish. Distinct Holiday beer.

Really great stuff.  Just what I was looking for.  A nice black pour with thin white head.  Aroma is amazing with great floral/spruce hops.  Taste is medium sweet and creamy with great hop flavor and bitterness.  NICE!

Bottle from Jaschais trade. This was more or less a typical porter, although very well made. It was a bit hoppier than I anticipated, but still full of chocolate bitterness and flavor. Pretty damn good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweet hoppy big porta. This is three
Floods nailing it again. Great job!!!!!!

Pours a nice dark brown.  A little hoppier than your typical Porter, but it is also better than your typical Porter.  The sugar gave it the perfect amount of sweetness.
