Nice to have a Christmas Ale that is a little different, and isnt over the top with nutmeg, ginger, all spice, etc.  I will look to have this again in the future around this time of year.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle.  It pours pitch black with a large, dark tan head of tight foam.  The head really hangs around.  The nose has a mix of roasted malt and pine.  The flavor mirrors the nose with some flint, chocolate, earth, and pine needle flavor.  Pretty even balance between the malt and the hops, with the hops edging things out a bit.  Full bodied with lots of softer carbonation leading to a medium finish.  Pretty damn good.

22 oz bottle acquired in trade with Wnoble. Pours dark like black coffee with a thick mocha colored head which stays together for quite a while.  Big roasted malt aroma with coffee, chocolate and an above average amount of floral hops. A bit less hop in the flavor than the aroma. Sweet malt flavor as well as bitter bakers chocolate and coffee bean.  Full palate with a finish that manages to be bitter and sweet at the same time.

From a 22oz bottle to a snifter.  Pours almost black with a brown head that lingers a bit.  Great nose with hints of coffee.  Good strong chocolate on the front with lots more grapefruity hops on the back than I was expecting.  Overall a great beer that lived up to my expectations.

I had really been looking forward to this one - and while it was a solid beer I was hoping for so much more. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a small white head that left no lacing. The aroma was dryish, roasty and had moderate floral hops and faint coffee. The flavor was dryish and roasty with notes of licorice, floral hops, fruity hops. coffee and a bit of apple. The finish was long and roasty with coffee, hops and anise lingering. Medium body. Solid.

What a great after-dinner Christmas beer!  Bomber from Archer Liquors in Chicago.  Pours pitch black with a chocolatey brown frothy head.  Aroma is a blast of piney hops, chocolate, and robust coffee.  Flavors evolve as the brew warms, from heavy hops and chocolate to a more complex mixture of black coffee, cocoa, and earthy hops.  Not terribly boozy, but just slightly more potent than a session beer.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Pours a dark brown, nearly black, with a tan head of foam that lingered for a little while and then dissipated to nearly nothing. Aroma is over the top chocolate, sugar, and coffee. Huge hop presence here as well. I get a big chocolate influence in the taste followed almost immediately by resinous hops and a mellow grapefruit. Earthy is a good way to describe this one. Drying with a long finish that leaves a roasty yet bitter taste on the back of the tongue with a bit of alcohol warmth.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2013 DARK brown color. Looks like a cup of espresso. Flavor of much more complex/strong than the nose. Aroma of dark chocolate. At first sip, carbonation catches the front of your tongue, dark chocolatey notes throughout, roasted malt, with a long bitter finish.

Pours from the bottle an opaque brown. Foam is tan and fizzy. Leaves some good lacing after it warms. Very hoppy aroma with some chocolate and malt notes. Thick body with good mouthfeel. Hops are apparent in the taste with vanilla, chcoclate, abd just a touch of roast and brown sugar. Finish is clean with little aftertaste. This is a good beer but not quite what I felt it was hyped up to be.

Pours black with a thin very light-brown head. Aroma is hoppy and herbal, also very sweet, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is bittersweet chocolate, coffee, some citrus and grass, and a flavor I cant quite identify (maybe the Mexican sugar? Not sure). More hoppy than I expected but overall quite nice.

Bomber from Secret Santa (Brad in Ohio). Thanks for this 100 pt beer! Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma has lots of chocolate and a strong hop character. Full bodied. Starts with a ton of resin and maybe grapefruit, quickly followed by a mass of very chocolate chocolate. Followed by some light  resin/grapefruit. Theres a lot of every thing is this drink that for me finishes pretty dry and nicely bitter. Thanks again Santa!
This one was ok but a bit lite. Caramel malt with slight chocolate taste lingers well. Kinda sweeter than I expect for the style

Bomber, poured into shaker. Pours black as a stout, almost no brown or ruby highlights. Half-finger of mocha head, spotty lacing. Nose is loaded with spruce-like hops, sharp piney overtones, with a roasted malt bitterness and citrus presence. Taste is a near-perfect harmony of piney hops, bitter, zesty citrus, and bitter chocolate, coffee, and roasted notes. Mouthfeel is full without verging on thick. Really wonderful stuff.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch frothy tan head.  Head retention is good, and theres a lot of lacing, too.  Aroma is roasty and hoppy, it smells like piney hops, roasted malt, coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  The taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but with the addition of some citrusy (grapefruit) hops.  None of the flavors overpower the other ones, which is a good thing in this case.  Theres also a nice bitter hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit creamy and coating, and is well carbonated.  I like this brew a lot, its really good hoppy porter.  Id certainly buy this again in the future, and its really worth trying if youve never had this before.

22 oz bottle poured into a snifter.

A: dark black with a dirty white/light brown head. After agitating the beer I got about 1/4 inch head.

S: Roasted coffee and sweet molasses/burnt sugar.

T: You get roasted coffee upfront with some malt sweetness, then you get a nice hop bitterness on he back of your tongue. 

Overall an interesting take on a porter. The hops make this a beer stand out from others porters and a must try.

Ive been looking forward to this one and it meets my high expectations.  At first whiff, it reminds me of Alpha King, not a porter  As soon as I poured it, I noticed a big difference.  Very dark brown, almost opaque black with a substantial tan head and lots of lacing.  Aroma isnt as hoppy/citrusy as the first smell.  Lots of coffee, chocolate, but some pine and citrus, as expected from FFF.   Carbonation is substantial and the body is as full as a porter should be.  A long almost bitter finish makes me look forward to the next taste.

Pours dark brown with light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and dark roasted malts.  Taste is sharp roasted dark malts, chocolate, coffee, and a semi-sweet finish.  Very nice creamy mouthfeel.  A very nice Christmas offering from 3floyds.

Wonderful deep brown to black pour with thick tan head and tons of lacing.  Aromas of coffee, toffee, chocolate, and notes of citrus.  Taste is bittersweet with great flavor.  Creamy texture, nice carbonation, and dry bitter finish.  Overall, this is an outstanding porter with great flavor and the hoppiness just makes it a pleasure to drink.

Aroma: mellow roasty malts, coffee, chocolate, pine and citrus hops, caramel and hints of sweetness.  Pours black, nice tan head with good retention.  Big chocolate and coffee flavors, roasty malts, just the right amount of background sweetness, nice balance of malt to hop flavors and bitterness.  Booze is well hidden, resin and citrus notes from the hops.  Medium-full body, medium carbonation.  Very nice.

Pours very dark reddish brown, you can tell its not cloudy but its dark enough that light cannot penetrate the center of the pint; dense, creamy beige head and retention for days.  Aroma is coffee, cream, bittersweet chocolate, a piney dry-hop presence, and tons of christmas cheer.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, pine needles, some deep fruit buried within the roast, cedar, aggressive burnt citrus finish.  Body is medium-full, creamy/frothy, low carb, dry roasted finish.  Overall, a seasonal favorite from 3F, warms me every winter.
On tap at 3 Floyds.  Black pour with a tan head.  Chocolate and dark roasted malt aromas.  The flavor follows suit.  A very nice imperial porter...

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a thick two finger beige head that slowly fades into a lasting ring. Chunks and streaks of lace coat the glass on the way down. 

Roasted malt aroma thats slightly smokey with hints of chocolate, caramel, oatmeal and toffee. Slightly balanced by earthy, piny hops. 

Thinner bodied than expected with some tight carbonation, possibly the beginning sign of oxidization. The hop presence is much stronger than the aroma hinted at making it very dry and bitter, outshining the roasted malt notes. Just too hoppy for the style in my opinion. Roasted malt backbone with dark chocolate, oatmeal, toffee, caramel and dark fruit. Smoother as it warms but still too hoppy with a dry finish.

Pours an almost pure black. The nose and taste is of chocolate, malts, and hops hops hops. Finishes with a bit of a tartness that rounds this beer out nicely. Its not for the faint of heart, there is a lot going on here, but it is another solid offering from FFF.
Pours dark with a rocky tan head. The aroma and taste are dominated by choclate and the finish is rather bitter but overall this is a very sweet porter. Not bad, a good seasonal brew.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Black in colour with medium carbonation. A nice blend of roasted and caramelized elements on the nose, along with some fairly forcefull herbal/minty hops. Well balanced on the palate, with coffee, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, mint, and rich pale malts all playing a role. Medium bodied and clean finishing. Perhaps a bit old as far as the hop potency goes, but well balanced and tasty as is.

Sample poured from 22oz bottle. Beautiful chocolate roast aroma, black color with a nice brown/tan head, light sweet with medium, woody bitterness, chocolate flavor, slight alcohol taste, medium body, creamy with a bitter finish. A great beer.

Pours black with a small and creamy brown head. Bisects chicolatey and lightly Biscuity and well balanced by fruity and citrus hops. Taste s chocolate and sone coffe supported by little evident sweetness but not dry by any means. A quality beer but hardly a porter by my standards.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2012 Bottle, courtesy of tarheels. Pours brown/black with a good head/retention. Aroma is all over the place: pine, wood, chocolate, olives, raisins, dates. Flavor is heavy raisins, chocolate, a bit of cinnamon/sugar going on. Palate is surprisingly light/dry, soft carbonation, very little bitterness. Interesting beer.

Re-rate: Fresh bottle, black pour, excellent retention/lace. Big hop aroma/taste, chocolate, some malt sweetness. Excellent soft/creamy palate. Very good.

651mL 2005 ed thanks to FlandersNed. The pour is a clear, deep black tea color looking true black in the snifter with a large, coffee head that sticks around nicely with decent webby lace. Nose is a little weird but no off flavors: sort of mustic attic (very strong), wet cedar, old pine cone/woodland potpourri, spicy meat, spicy lemon/lemon tea. But then it quickly devolves to classic black olives and brine that plague heavy stouts/porters. This is thankfully balanced by heavy raisins and Raisinettes. Taste is not too heavy with nice spicy potpourri, cinnamon, leaves, spicy orange peel and dried lemon. Palate feels thinner, light lemon with a slight tang but lots of cocoa butter and thick chocolate in the finish. Strange but not so much a heavy Imperial Porter as much as what it was meant to be, a classic London porter albeit with a little heavier dose of bitter chocolate and spice medley. Very complex- you gotta love it for that- but I cant really rave about it.

Stimmig malziger und röstiger Antrunk mit kaffeeartigem Anteil. Das Aroma wird breiter, die röstigen Noten intensivieren sich leicht. Dazu kommt eine angenehme Süße, die aber nur wenig erkennbar ist. Die Kaffeenoten werden etwas stärker, das Bier bleibt auf hohem Niveau. Schokoladiger Abgang mit hefigen Noten, herb, angenehm. Gelungen! 8/10/9/11/11/11
poured from a 22 oz  blackish brown color with a  dark cream head.  Smell is of dried fruties and chocolate.  Taste is of chocolate and fruit this is a cool beer. very smooth mouth feel.
Pours deep brown with notes of chocolate and caramel. It drives on the heavy side and gives a nice choclate and dried date kick.

Bottle (09 notes, Indianapolis).  Pours dark mahogany, with a tannish head.  Lots of chocolate, some sweetness, dark fruits, and light roast come into the aroma.  I was really surprised by how hoppy this is, with grapefruit and resin contributing to the loads of chocolate.  Medium to thicker body with softer carbonation.  Nice.

Bomber.  Pours dark brown with an average tan head.  Complex aroma with heavy raisin, dark chocolate and bitter, earthy tones.  Flavor consists of milk chocolate, ripe fruit, smoke and oak. Very sweet up front but finishes with a cocoa tartness.  Creamy texture with carbonation on the softer side.  Great sipping brew and one of the most interesting porters Ive encountered.

Well I have confirmed my suspicion. I think I personally dont care for Porters too often. On the other hand I do like them to a point. This one was one of the better Porters I have had, but not better than Founders Porter. It was good and it achieved the mark.

This beer pours black with about 2 fingers of medium tan head. The retention is really good as it takes about 5 minutes to go down completely. As it falls there a nice chunks and lots of soapy lacing that covers all sides of the glass. 

The aroma is very very strong. It smells like smoke which is amazing to me, never smelled that in anything other than a rauch. There are also some notes of oak and coffee.

The taste is also wood/smoke that is quite intriguing. I would have thought this was a smoked porter. There are small hints of hops and coffee.

Aroma wow this is intense sweet, super hoppy, spices, grassy, earthy, chocolaty ... almost to much to describe major hop emphasis. Pour super deep brown with caramel finger head and good lacing. Taste chocolate, coffee, grassy/piney hops, cinnamon other seasonal spices. Mf full body relatively thick and creamy with a mild carb and great bitter lingering. Overall a ridiculous brew that I would try to procure at any cost do not miss.

A good porter, though not a great one. Pours a nice deep brown with a good-sized head which stays up for a while. Nice flavor of roasted grain and chocolate, with some coffee and fruits present. Decent level of carbonation with a fairly bubbly mouthfeel. I enjoyed it, though dont know Id seek it out.

Bomber, Pours a light molasses w. a clumpy off-white head. Aroma is great blend of roastiness, chocolate, and piney resins. Flavor is sweet and smooth with light hop resins on finish but no bitter or roast lingering. Fantastic smooth flavorful brew.
Poured from a 650ml bottle.  Pours black with lots of tan/beige head.  Smell is hops and some toasted malts.  Taste is very hop forward with a nice balance of sweetness and bitterness.

A: The pour is a dark brown color with some definite red highlights. A short lived off-white head is present, too.

S: Quite a lot of roast, and perhaps char, with just a touch of smokiness. There are some nice hints of dark fruits, earthy hops, and bitter dark chocolate. I seem to pick up just a touch of licorice.

T: Mostly roasted malt flavor with a nice char character. A mild sweetness in the form of toffee, and the same earthy hop notes. A mild to moderate bitterness to the beer.

M: Medium in body and medium carbonation, too.

D: Kind of heavy on the roast which limits the amount of other qualities you can pick up, but good.

The aroma is malty, hints of coffee, a touch anise, cocoa and fig.  Pours dark brown with a light brown head, mostly diminishing, excellent lacing. The flavor is bitter. The body is creamy, just a touch watery. Smoky flavor smooth.  Very good!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 22 oz bomber. 2009 Vintage.

Pours a dark, dark blackish brown with hints of light ruby brown on the edge. The head is decently sized, tan, and recedes with some nice lacing.

First off in the smell it has a nice hop profile with piney, earthy hops. The malts have both chocolate and roasted coffee characters.

The hops arent as evident in the taste but this is a straight up KICK ass porter, it just overtook Black Butte for me. It has light roasty flavors, plenty of sweetness, chocolate, some fruitiness, and a nice large backing of super piney hops. This is a winter beer for all winter beers.

The mouthfeel is near perfect, with decent carbonation but a big, full mouthfeel. Drinkability is excellent.

This is a freakin amazing brew, luckily there is a huge stash at the store near me, I might have to go stock up for the summer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-06-2010 02:57:33

Poured into a snifter. I believe this is an 09.

4.5 A: Pours a black color. Two fingers of dense creamy light brown head. Good retention and some lacing.

4.0 S: Lot of chocolate in this one. Toasted and roasted malts next. Hop character is subtle at this point, but is herbal and citrusy.

4.0 T: The taste is still pretty hoppy however. Orange, pine, and grapefruit hops are most powerful and give an almost sourish flavor. Roasty, but more so toasty and burnt flavors. Some grainy malts as well.

4.5 M: Medium body. Moderate amounts of carbonation. Reasonably creamy and quite smooth.

4.0 D: Good hoppy porter. Definitely a good one to try. Solid in each category.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2010 01:00:47

220z traded bottle. Pours a nice dark brown, almost black color, with a bubbly brown head. Some lacing. Nice big aroma of chocolate and coffee plus some sweetness. Flavor is more coffee plus a little heat. Finishes a little sweet. Nice and pleasant.

Bottle. Pour is black brown and has a tight tan head that fades. Aroma is roasted malt and fresh coffee with some coco too. Taste has more coffee and coco some peat along with a good hoppy backbone. Palate is medium chaulky feel that has a subtle carbonation and finishes dry. Well done!

Huge aroma of chocolate with a roasted caramel taste. Palate is slightly syrupy. Warm but still hides the alcohol taste. Overall a nice choice for a brutally cold Saturday afternoon like today.  As this started to warm up it kind of turned into a syrupy taste that I think was masked by the coldness at first.  Pretty good, but not my favorite.  I agree with it being more of a stout style.

Pours a solid black with a creamy off white head that sticks around for a while before attaching itself to the sides of my glass. Aroma is chocolate, bitter roasted malts, throw in a slight alcohol aroma as well. Tastes of chocolates and coffees, reminds me more of a stout than a porter, but that line is so blurry these days. Smooth creamy mouthfeel with a hint of hops in the finish. Ample carbonation. Solid brew all around.

Bottle. Poured into a New Belgium tulip glass a dark brown color with a fluffy mocha fan head of 2 fingers. The aroma is a nice blend of chocolate and hops. Almost has a spice to it as well in the nose. Nice lace as the head settles. Medium mouthfeel. Cocoa like sweetness up front with a transition to a dark chocolate bitterness. The hollow are pretty bold towered the end as well. Slight booze.

Surprisingly mild aroma gives way to initial sweetness followed by a nice bitter slap on the swallow. The body is lighter than most porters and the finish is pretty quick. A solid porter, but it does not strike me as worthy of its 100 rating.

7th December 2008  Made with Mexican sugar. Dark brown porter with a very frothy tan head. Rich and strong. Subtle chocolate and a dark fruity note. The big frothy head gives a creamy feel but the finish is coffee and hop bitter.

Bottle courtesy Josh - thank you!  Thin brown head; quickly fading.  Pine, resinous hops aroma - wow!  Taste is heavy resinous pine followed by somewhat roasted malt, some light chocolate and spices, and more hops on the finish.  Feels a bit light in the mouth but not to the beers detriment.  Damn good beer.

650 ml bottle thats been aged in cellar for at least a year, poured into a snifter glass. Dark brown, black, with a tannish brown head. Beer is very dark, thick and opaque. Roasted malt flavors including some chocolate flavors.  Semi-sweet taste of cocoa initially, followed by a little bit of a cocoa-mint taste. Finishes with more cocoa flavors and just a little hint of roasted coffee. Creamy mouthfeel reminds me of chocolate milk, just enough carbonation. Nice sipping beer on a cold winter night. Very smooth and easily drinkable at 6%.

Tasted on 1/7/11 from a 22oz bomber bottle purchased at Kenwood, I am pretty sure this bottle is from 2009.  Pours a nearly black and nearly opaque amber with a thick beige head that slowly recedes to leave a still rather thick and even blanket of lace.  The nose is dark roasted malt, coffee, prune, raisin, fig, somewhat creamy, grapefruit peel, and light pine resin.  The flavor is sweet brown sugar and fruits up front, moving to chocolate, and somewhat bitter hops on the middle, and dark chocolate, coffee, and burnt brown sugar on the back.  The body full with average, but creamy, carbonation, and a long complex finish that features all of the flavors mentioned in this review.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2012 Location/Date: Bottle split with Dave on January 31st, 2012.
Appearance: Pours black with red head. 
Aroma: Aroma is chocolate, malt, some of hops.
Taste: Nice bitterness, chocolate, nice amount of malt.
Palate: Medium body, smooth.
Summary: I love porters, I love hops, so I love this beer.

An extremely hoppy chocolaty porter. Pretty interesting. Bottle acquired with friend Dave.  Pours a nice dark color, almost like a stout.  Usual interesting hop nose from Three Floyds. Finishes like a porter. Good beer.

Notes from 12/30/2010
22 oz. bottle

Ar: Deep roasted malt (coffee, chocolate) with a touch of smoke.
Ap: Beautiful.  3/4" cinnamon head.  Served @ 55F in a snifter.  Deep black, great head retention.
T: Roasty goodness.  Properly roasted coffee and 85% dark chocolate.  Great hop bittering cuts through the intense richness.
P: Thick, oily body.  High carbonation for the style.

O: World class offering from FFF.

I think this might be the most "not normal" beer they make.  To me its a chocolatey porter crossed with dreadnaught.  HUGE hop aroma with 3F typical citrusy notes.  I never expect a porter to have that smell, it took me off guard.  Then a big blast of hops at the front of the palate transitioning to chocolate malt and a roasty finish.  Very weird, pretty tasty.

Bottle.  Pour is deep deep brown with a smallish tan head that quickly dissipates to a thin ring of tan foam.  Aroma is very rich with loads of sweet roasted malt, rich brown sugar, light coffee, light dark fruit, and a notable hop presence.  Flavor is very true to nose with a mildly lighter body than expected.  Flavor is roasted malt with hints of brown sugar, hop notes, light coffee, faint fruit, and a dry but smooth roasted malt finish.  It has been a while since I have had this, and it is better than I remember.

Thanks Gcurlow for the bottle! It pours dark brown with a creamy tan colored head. The aroma is hoppy and roasted with sweet chocolate, oranges, coffee, toffee, and pine. The flavor is the same with the fruity, bitter hops melding nicely with the sweeter caramel and toffee flavors. It all comes together nicely with an ashy roasted, chocolaty finish.

Chocolate and caramel aroma. Not as heavy as you would expect, but still maintains a smooth, bubbly texture. Very nice Christmas beer that is filling, but not too filling to have a big glass for desert.

Bomber. Pours black with a half inch head that quickly recedes. Aroma is chocolate. Flavor is also chocolate with surprisingly little hoppiness for a porter, but enough to balance the malty sweetness. Fantastic brew.

Thanks to NBondi for the bottle. Dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma has lots of big citrusy hops, as well as chocolate caramel and cinnamon. Taste is big smooth malt, lots of toffee, chocolate and notes of citrus all popping through. A really well made porter.

Bomber acquired via trade. Pitch black pour, light tan head and solid lacing. Smells of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, some citrus hops?! Tastes initially of roast and coffee, follows up with a burst of citrus and pine hops, finishes with more roast. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, quite enjoyable brew.

Bottle....  Poured deep, dark brown-near black with a tan head.  Holy smokes!.. Lots of hops on the nose with a lot of roast.  Near CDA style?  Sweet, malty, smokey, roast, and a residual bitterness from all the hoppiness going on.

Bottle From Downer Wine and Spirits.  Pours a jet black with thin tan.  Aroma is roasted malt.  Heavy on the palate with medium carbonation.  Flavor is roasted malt, mild hop, and a nice resdiual sweetness.  A Christmas beed I look forward to every year!

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with James and Sean. Pours a deep, opaque obsidian with a frothy, beige head. Dissipates quickly, leaving a ring around the glass. Aroma of fresh peppers, coffee beans, lactose, Belgian candied sugars, chocolate, honey, peppermint, and barley. Medium bodied with a slightly chalky, yet smooth and spicy palate. Full, rich finish. Great Christmas porter.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2012 Bottle split with and courtesy of pat. Pours pitch blackish brown mahogany body. Aroma is deep, spicy roast, toffee, and caramel. Mouthfeel is extremely smooth with notes of sweet roast, bread, fresh hops, toast, and holiday spices.

Pours a dark brown with a billowing dark cream colored head. Heavy chocolate, coffee and vanilla aromas. Well balanced flavor, the hops surprisingly shine through and blend with a rich and robust malty backbone. Phenomenally well balanced.

On tap at Sergios.  Pours black with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of smokiness, hops, and chocolate.  Flavor strong of the hops, with a little smokiness/dark chocolate.  Nice texture, but could be thicker.  A really good beer.

Bomber btl. Super dark brown with a foaming dark tan head. Really piney hop aroma with some nice chocolate notes. A really hoppy porter! Medium chocolate malt body with some seious hop blasts. A pleasant slightly bitter finish. Really surprised by the intense hop profile I can see how people dig this. Not my favorite but Id like to try it again.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at the FFF Brewpub in November 2009.

Pours a very, very dark brown with a moderately-brown head. Hops are at the forefront of this one, with a bit of dark chocolate, coffee, and roast coming through in the background. The taste is quite similar, with an amazing amount of piney hops coming through alongside a little bit of citrus. Chocolate and coffee also make an appearance. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and well-carbonated. Overall, a little intense and heavy for extended drinking, but definitely an absolutely delicious beer.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-23-2010

The aroma on this porter is hoppy....like an IPA, strangely enough, though it is mixed with hints of chocolate. If I were to be blindfolded, I would have a hard time telling whether the brew was a porter or an IPA. The head is a rich brown, while the brew is so deeply dark that it appears black. The head never settles completely, leaving tendrils of light brown on the glass. The taste is a balance of chocolate and hops, just like the aroma suggests. The flavor of sugar follows the body almost immediately, adding to the smoothness of the brews impact on the palate. This has just the right amount of carbonation to make it work without ruining it, tingling the tongue well short of irritation. This is a heavy work, no doubt, but well done enough that I wish I had purchased two 22s.
UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 On tap at FFF. Almost black appearance with a tan head. Aroma and flavor is of dark roasted malts, chocolate, and some piney hops. Tastes somewhat like a black ipa like. Solid.

Really great beer in abottle brought from West Lafayette.  Much like Storm king, but with the lower alcohol smoother with plenty of coffee and juniper notes, finishing with the coffee sweetnes and a good slug of hops.  Looks great pouring like thin used motor loi, fair head but plenty of lacing

Poured from bomber, pours a nice black color with a thick tan head, the aroma is roasty and has some chocolate on the nose as well, the flavor is very complex and has touches of chocolate, its roasty and even has a kick of hops, this is one impressive brew.

Bottle.  Pours black with a tall dense creamy khaki colored head that leaves beautiful lace.  OH MY GODDD! This aroma is fantastic!!  Very hoppy (citrus and resinous) commingling with very roasty coffee notes and some bitter dark as well as light milk chocolate.  Jesus, just so much going on here.  The thought of hops and roastiness seems odd, and can be, but FFF has made reached some magical ratio.  The flavor is good, very good, but somehow not as magical as the aroma.  The roastiness is very pleasant and exhibits some great coffee quality.  Its medium to full bodied with low carbonation.  Overall:  I know this beer was going to be good, but I was nowhere near ready for its true awesomeness.  I dont know if this is just a particularly good batch (and I am getting it really fresh), but I would think this would be a top 50 beer if everyone who rated it were drinking out of my glass right now.  Cheers FFF, yet another mind blowing beer!

Bottle from Binnys today. 

Nice dark umber, almost black pour, big tan head. 

Nose is dark chocolate, as well as piney hops with a hint of interesting wintergreen. Some malt notes as well. 

Palate is again bittersweet chocolate, pine hops, baking spices, and a bit of a balanced finish.

Palate is solid, no quirks.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Re-rate - certainly a new bottle (different label than the prior) from Discount Waukesha.  Pours that same inky black.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted coffee and GRASSY HOPS.  Taste is smoooooooth chocolate with roast malts.  Long mellow finish.  Thanks for coming back hops!!  Original rating - Bomber from Rays in Tosa that they insist is new.  Pours inky but not totally black with 1/2 inch cafe au lait head.  Smelling soy sauce, coffee beans and chocolate (where is the fresh mown grass?).  Taste is a nice mellow mocha bittersweet chocolate (again, no HOPS?), perhaps a bit thin.  Once again, a rite of the season has come up uneven this year from FFF -- in a few of the past several years, the hoppiness showing through the porter was stellar.  This years version is fine and fairly tasty, however short of prior years. 7.4.7.3.14

[650ml bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Pours brownish/black with a light beige head. Great roasty porter aroma with a decent hop profile. Roasted malt on the palate, with a coffee finish, then chocolate. I didnt pick up any spice flavour  but there are some hops going on. These days people expect Christmas Beers to be overly spiced  but Im glad some stick to other paths [14112010]
Had on draft at FFF brewpub.  This is a fantastic, well-balanced porter.  Hoppy, yet roasty.  I made the trip from Michigan to pick up a case of bombers and Im glad I did.  Well done!

On tap at FFF; pour is very dark, nice tan head with excellent lacing on this one. Aroma gives you yes indeed that alpha king element. But theres also a roastiness as well. Flavors are light piney hops, roasted chocolate malt, a hint of Mexican sugars. The hops provide a touch of bitterness, but theres also of course a bit of sweetness as well. Excellent brew!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2011 Black with tan head.  Roasted malts, hops, and faint background fruit.  Flavor leans toward the chocolately end with nice residual hopping.  Somewhat nutty.  Good but not great. (original rating 3.9)

Re-rate (3/9/2011): Fresh 2010 bottle.  Hops definitely popping out a bit better in the aroma with chocolate behind that.  Strong bitterness that morphs to cocoa then back to an earthy hoppiness. +1
Pours jet black with a brown head, nose is hoppy and fruity, taste is dry and warming, chocolate and dark fruit.

A: Looks like a glass of Coca-Cola. An impenetrable blackish brown, with a light tan-ish head. better than average retnetion level with a wonderful amount of lacing.

S: wow thats a funky smelling porter. smells like a great breakfast, pot and coffee. or a pot of coffee ;) huge roasted malts, some chocolate notes, but a ton of hops leading to a MJ aroma and a little coffee.

T: great flavors. tons of roasted malts, chocolate, toffee notes, and some coffee and caramel. big hopped up flavors. wow this is delightful. its like smoking a J and taking a big sip of black coffee.
Merry Christmas to me.

M: big and bold for the style. medium carbonation level. full bodied for the style. very sharp.

D: major credit for creativity with the style and flavor combination. 7.5% makes it a bomber only for me but a great one at that. Absolutely wonderful, believe the hype.

Thanks for DosBeerigos for sharing this one. The pour was dark brown and was a little transparent when held up to the light. The aroma was sweet with roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee grind. Definitely a beer for Christmas.

Bomber; thanks to deyholla for the bottle and chance to revisit; pours dark cola brown and clear with thin tan head; sweet, raw choco powder with brown sugar and rum; plenty sweet on first sip with a nutty, dry chocolate finish; a little tobacco and sweet chocolate with thin texture and light body overall; some caramel and mild milky-ness; candy malts, raw and thin; a little ashy with a thin, caramel sweetness; good stuff, but less impressed as I was previously; dry nuts, peanut shells, bitter chocolate

Original Rating 4/16/08 (Score - 4.2): 22 oz. bottle; thanks SQNfan!!! was eager to try this for a while and it didnt disappoint; pours thin and slightly off white head fades immediately; aromas of coffee and dank fruit; thin body with flavors of bitter chocolate and a dry finish; everything improves with temp; hop aromas come out at the bottom of the glass as it gets more syrupy; a great porter and FFF strikes again

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is strong toffee malt and coffee. The flavor is coffee and roasted malt. The flavor is pretty basic American porter. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
thanks to Hophead22 for the tasting.,From a 22oz bottle,Malty smell and black in color.

Pours a dark black with a ruby color with a very big dense tan head (around 2 inches). Aroma has a strong chocolate malt, mild toasted malt note, some spicy notes and a strong citrus hops presence. Flavor has a strong sweet chocolate up front that moves into a light spicy and toasted malt note with a strong finishing happiness that adds a little sweetness and a mild orange citrus like flavor. Body was heavy with a low fine carbonation that produced a nice head retention and great lacing. Overall a very solid brew in which the chocolate really stands out with a fantastically matching hops flavor.
Sampled from a 22oz bottle. Pours a rich bark color with a tan head. Aroma is rich and creamy, chocolate, smooth, very nice. Quite drinkable.

22oz bottle thanks to peter. Pours black with lively tan head. Aroma is abit astringent, dark roasted grain, licorice and faint smoke. Flavor is the same with an added hop kick, chocolate and a bit of brett. Mouth feel is medium body with high, fizzy carbonation. Overall, not bad at all!

thanks to peter for this one.  poured black with a beige head.  aroma was dark roast, spice, and rye???  flavor was dark roast, spice, bitter coffee, and chocolate.  medium body with medium carbonation.

Pours a black color with a big semi loose head that leaves lots of pretty lace. The aroma is tons of fresh hops way way more than I would expect in a Christmas beer in late April. There is some nice chocolate and mocha in there along with some fruitiness primarily from hops but also from yeast, a little licorice sneaks in the nose as well. The flavor is plenty of chocolate both milk & dark with some mild smoky coffee and plenty of fruity hoppiness. The palate is full and slightly slick. Delicious.

Bottle, courtesy of bulldogp04.  Poured black with a tall beige head.  Huge primary notes in the nose of roast, coffee, and chocolate, secondary notes of pine, grass, and light citrus.  Fairly full body with a viscous mouth feel and gentle carbonation.  Awesome beer, more of a hoppy dry stout.  Lots of coffee and chocolate flavors, some heavily roasted or burnt malt a touch of vanilla, the hop presence really just puts this beer over the top for me.  It disappears way to quick.
Oh no! Nose is medicinal, which is pretty disappointing. Strong roasted flavor saves the day.

opaque black, creamy tan head, high co2, full-body.

aroma: coffee, bit of bitter chocolate, slight silage.

taste:
T1= chocolate, co2, bit of leafy hops.
T2= roasted malt, charcoal, silage, herbal hops.
T3= fairly clean.

not very smooth or complex, mostly just charcoal and carbonation.

(22oz bottle thanks to peter) deep brown pour with lasting deep brown bubbles. Nose of roasted nuts, brown sugar, and pumpernickel bread. Taste of brown sugar, pumpernickel bread, cola, and lightly roasted nuts. Very well carbonated and creamy body.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2010 22oz bomber, 2008 edition, courtesy of alexsdad06. thanks, brad! pours a dark, cola brown, damn near black with a solid, beige head leaving a tight right of lace. aroma is excellent with huge notes of bakers chocolate, ashy roast, mild coffee, and cinnamon with a touch of caramel sauce and a distinctive, earthy, herbal hop presence that im actually glad has had some time to tone down as it meshes perfectly with the rest of the aroma. flavor is absolutely wonderful and just as with the aroma, the massive hop presence has toned down over time leading to a perfectly balance brew with spicy, herbal, earthy, hops up front with sweet caramel malts leading the transition to big roast coffee, wood, dark chocolate, and light licorice with a touch of vanilla. palate is medium bodied with light carbonation and a lingering, roasted, chocolatey finish. overall, one of the best strong porters out there.
22 ounce bomber .A dark pour with lite brown head taste o fchocolate, coffee, roasty, good  hop finish

my second best porter i have had. chocolate aroma and flavor with sweet mexican sugar. nice black color with a bit of a head and descent lacing. i would only be able to drink one of these in a sitting though as it is a bit to sweet. oh yea nice citrus hops in this thing which makes it a bit more palatable.

220z bomber bottle.  Pours a thick opaque brown-lack, with and impressively stable beige head.  Wow.  This beer is phenomenal.  Creamy and soft on the palate, lots of cocoa chocolate tones with an interesting hop balance to boot.  Bold, but the reasonable 7.5% ABV keeps it highly drinkable.  There is a slight pungent chocolate taste, not unlike a Caribbean Stout in some respects, but the odd hoppiness twist and tweaks it into its own realm.  Pleasant bitter chocolate tones, never overly thick or sticky.  There is an almost herbal/spicy feel, not unlike Anchor OSA.  This really takes the Porter style and turns it into something new and exciting, while retaining its classic qualities as well.  World Class.

Bottle via trade thanks to deliriumfest on BA.  Pours jet black and viscous with a large creamy tan head that lasts and leaves great lacing.  Aroma is awesome and intense: chocolate, coffee, roast, spice, and floral hops.  Flavor is also excellent and just HUGE.  Chocolate, roast, and coffee dominate, but theres also caramel, spices, and loads of floral and piney hops on the finish.  Body is full and mouthfeel is a little syrupy but not overwhelming.  Overall, this is just excellent stuff.  Say what you want about Dark Lord (I say its awesome), but if you dont think Three Floyds is one of the best in the business, in the words of Ice Cube, you better "chiggity-check yo self before you wriggity-wreck yo self."

Bottle shared with Plovmand. Black body with a medium quick dissapering brown head. Aroma is hops, chocolate and notes of tobacco. Flavor is hops, roasted malt and chocolate. Well balanced and very drinkable.

Draft @ Three Floyds, Munster, IN. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty hoppy chocolate aroma. Roasted malty malty hoppy bitter chocolate flavor with some hints of coffee. Has a roasted malty hoppy bitter chocolate finish with a long bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 On tap at Ervs Mug.  Very dark brown with a creamy brown crown that leaves behind copious amounts of lace.  Aroma of pine, dark roasted malts, citrus and coffee.  Taste is nice and hoppy with pine, citrus and balanced out with dark roasted malts, chocolate and mild sugar.  Moderate bitter finish.

7-4-8-4-15 2-26-10
Dark brown with a thin tan head and minor lacing.  Aroma of dark roasted malts, chocolate, spices and enough of a hop presence to make you notice.  Taste of spice, caramel, dark malts, brown sugar, licorice and chocolate.  Some hops are mixed and you get a mild bitter finish thats part hoppy and part dark chocolate.  Not bad.

"Im a sucker for dark well hopped beers and this delivered. Shared by a generous friend, Im glad to have enjoyed a glassful of this mighty fine porter. Dark body with a huge brown head and good lacing. Roasted malts, nutty, and fruity aromas are intertwined with floral hops. Full bodied, balanced and easy on the palate. Big hoppy flavor of flowers, citrus and pine. Notes of chocolate, burnt toast, caramel and nuts. Damn good."

Thanks to Plovmand and Hallinghansen for sharing. Black with a tiny tan head. Roasted aroma of licorice and rich dark chocolate with hoppy citrus and pine notes. Dry and bitter flavour with lots of cocoa and mild roasted notes.

Bomber, shared by my man Zack Atak in the muthafuzzin hizzy, yow!  Pours blackish-brownish-ebon with v.v. little head. Aroma is predominantly coffee/chocolate/roast, but is accentuated by hoppy goodness. Flavor follows, with everything in perfect balance. Mouthfeel is silky and substantial with low carbonation.  Truly the king of porters.

Bottle. Shared with hallinghansen. Pitch black with a dense tan head. Sweet roasty aroma with barley and fruity hoppy notes. Light tobacco notes and ripe fruit. Light tobacco, dusty fruity hops, roasted malt and spruce. It ends up fruity sprucy hoppy with a good roasty kick. Very nice.

Thanks to Santa for this.  Pours a deep dark brown with a brown head.  Aroma is sweet malt and chocolate.  Taste is well balanced and complex.  Roasted malt, chocolate and faint coffee.  There is even some mild hop bitterness in the aftertaste.  A really good beer and Im not a big porter fan but Ill drink this any day.

Draft. Super dark espresso brown color. Toasty caramel aroma. Strong coffee flavor. Roasted malts, chocolate, a hint of citrus, and vanilla. Each sip is a delight. Definitely characteristic of three Floyds - its Alpha Kings stonger tasting brother. Dry, hoppy and bitter. Doesnt leave an unpleasant aftertaste. Love it!

22 oz. bottle picked up for me by shawnm213 at City-Wide in South Bend- thanks, Shawn!  Pours a very dark brown with a 1-inch thick brown head.  Nice aroma of citrusy hops, dark chocolate, coffee, ripe mixed fruits, earth, and roasted malts.  The flavor also has more hops, fruit, and chocolate than a typical porter, with notes of dirt, smoked meat, and roast.  Medium-full bodied, with a chocolaty mouthfeel and good hop bitterness to offset the chocolate and fruit sweetness.  Dry finish.  I expected more winter spices, but this went a totally different direction.  Awesome imperial porter.

Bottle. Poured an opaque black color. The head was tall and brown with good retention and lacing. Smelled of equal parts molasses, chocolate, and coffee. Medium bodied and slightly sweet with moderate to high carbonation and moderate bitterness. I tasted chocolate, pine, and roasty malt.
poured very dark with a nice tan head smelled of chocolate, hops and toasted malts.  tasted alot of roasted malts with slight alcohol and some hop character.  very good

22oz bottle from Whole Foods Chicago. Intense thick brown colour, with tan head. Aroma of toasted malt and strong hoppy character. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee dried fruit and noticeable hops. Slight traces of spice. Lingering finish and aftertaste, with slight astringent character..

Bouteille de 22 oz. Arômes de houblon floral et de chocolat. Robe noire, légère mousse moka et effervescence moyenne. Moyennement ronde en bouche, une très belle touche de cacao est accompagnée de céréales et dun houblon floral aromatique. Finale relativement douce de chocolat et légèrement amère. Lalcool est très peu apparent. Une très bonne porter.
Hot damn!  this lived up to my expectations.  second three floyds beer ive had and so far they are 2 for 2.  dark brown porter with overwhelming amount of hop taste and aroma.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black. Massive tan head. Stays forever with maximum lacing.Very hoppy nose like an ipa. Flavor an instant hit of coffee. Strangely, the hops are very minimal, unlike the aroma. Very malty. Delicately balanced! Slightly thinner on the palate then I would have liked. Lively carbonation that fits the style very well. Overall, fantastic.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with slight ruby notes at the corners and a tan head.  The nose is slightly dusty with nice roasted malt notes and the body is lighter than expected.  The frothy head almost completely dissolves into the body during a drink.  Flavors of blackberries, dried sweet cherries and maybe some plums compliment the nice chocolate malts.  I was expecting some traditional holiday spices but the only trace I got was on some grainy sugar.  Very very nicely done, but still a big sugary beer.

Bottle from a trade with StFun.  Pours black with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and pine hops. Burnt malts, coffee and chocolate flavors with lots of pine hops. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Its a good beer but something about the flavor combinations doesnt click for me.  Thanks Josh.

Bottle. Pours black with slight brown edge and some light tan head. Nose is border-line dreadnaught blanketing dark malts. Flavor is as much hops as you could ever hope for in a porter. The porter flavor is still smooth and solid, yet infused with hops. I love FFF, and I love hops, yet I am starting to wonder why every big beer from them is hop overload. Its not even a bad thing, and Im not even complaining. I guess I would just like a year round IS, not a once a year offering. Merry Christmas!

Pours a thick espresso brown with thick tan head. Aroma is heavy alcohol and raisin with very sweet sugar notes. Flavor is a sweet raisin with vanilla and coffee. Body is creamy with mild carbonation.

Bottle. Thanks to 17th floor for the hookup! Pours a deep inky brown with an espresso colored foamy head. Flavor is dark dry roast, hints of coffee and chocolate, has that nice sugar punch that I love about 3F. Finishes with a nice chunk of pine like American hop presence. Minor alcohol finish. This is as good as it gets for an Xmas beer! Nothing like Xmas Ale on Xmas Eve! Cheers!

Poured thick black with off brown head, smelled of thick smoke and hops. Taste starts out with hoppiness characteristic of 3 Floyds, then levels out into dark malt with coffee and chocolate that levels into a smoky finish. Excellent porter!

StLHops tasting.  This looks pretty much like a porter.  Nose is smoky ash tray which also describes the flavor.  This porter offers the biggest hop profile of any I have tasted.  Those hops provide a nice and surprising effervescence.  A very nice beer but too much ash for me.

2009 Bomber from the very expensive Liquor Stop. Pours a little darker than Coca-Cola with a med. brown head that sticks along the edge and very light fast lace.The aroma has more wet hops than I can remember on any IPA much less a Porter: spicy pine, hints of lime, sour candy and, actually, Coca-Cola! Delicious! Such a mixture of roast malts and hops - its not normal! Taragon, basil, black coffee, perhaps a bit of the darkest chocolate, the flavor is not quite as lively as the aroma, but this may be the best flavor/price ratio of any beer even at Liquor Stop. The finish is coffee all the way out.

This beer poured a real dark black with little head, but what was there was really tan and almost caramel like.  

At first I almost smelled a strong red wine in the nose similar to a port. Coffee taste with a hint of cherries and a nice hop induced bitterness.

I am a novice to this style, but this was thoroughly enjoyed.

Bottle from StFun that I took to my first show and tell at "The Bruery". Poured a dark brown color with tan head. Aroma was spicey, roasty and had almost a vodka aroma to it. Taste was spices, peeted malts, and some smoke. Pallet was medium and very smooth. Overall very enjoyable.
Bomber from FFF.  Thick black pour, brownish head. Nice hop aroma. Semi-creamy, semi-carbonated, hoppy / bitter chocolate in the taste.

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan coffee head.  Chocolate, minerals, roast y earth coffee toned bitterness.  Chewy lush ash y caramel notes.  Roasted coffee toned hop character to finish.  For hoppy and dark personally id go with dark hops, however this was a favorite amongst the friends that i shared this with, to bad FFF, doesnt distribute to jersey anymore.

Aside from the creepy label, this beer is really good.  I had a holiday ale tasting and this easily beat out Bells and Southern Tier.  Great chocolate brown color.  Coffee notes.  A little sweetness.  Great example of a winter wamer.

Pours dark brown with a thick foamy head.  At first there was a strong hop aroma that overpowered everything else.  Once the beer warmed up I was able to pick up caramel and chocolate aromas in addition to the hops.  This beer has a nice creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Caramel, chocolate, vanilla, and roasted malt flavors at the beginning.  Then the hops kick in for a bitter hop finish.   This is a very nice hoppy porter.

Pours a dark, dark brown out of the bottle that looks black in the glass.  Smell is mainly hops, which took me off guard for a porter.  There is some burnt coffee and chocolate in there too, but hard to get past the hops. Taste picks up where the aroma left off with lots of hops but with vanilla and maybe some oatmeal in the background.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2009 Served on draft @ Map Room in Chicago.  This is the hoppiest porter Ive ever had, but then again its Three Floyds so I cant say Im surprised.  Aroma is very unique, upon first sniff the first word that came to mind was "fresh", which sounds pretty stupid but whatever. Its more hoppy than anything else, which is odd for a porter but Im into it.  Would recommend.

Like a chocolate coffee ipa. Also some floral-ness and grapefruit. Delicious. Sweetness is at the right level, its not overpowering, ashiness is minimal, and it is very unique. Maybe not that unique - but it is way more successful than other hoppy dark beers Ive tried. A good thing to drink the day before you go to the frickin VIRGIN ISLANDS with Erin, dammit! Jealous? Yeah, you are.

Bottle thanks to TearsforBears my secret santa!Near-black with a nice beige head that drops quickly. Nose is a fantastic balance of bitter roasted malt, like coffee, and as strong a milk chocolate as Ive smelled in a beer. Flavor is milky and roasty, but the coffee hits wonderfully in the back half and continues through the finish. A little green and thin, the body could use a light boost. Not incredibly complex, but this kind of balance from FFF is stunning, and the lack of sugar overkill is equally as impressive. Total enjoyment.
Pours a very dark red. lasting head with consistent lacing. The hops took a backseat to the strong roasted malts. Thin. No sweetness. Enjoyable.

Bottle thanks to shawn. Black pour with some tan head. Coffee, chocolate, sugar, roasted malts, some vanilla and hop notes. Velvety smooth porter with a slight alcohol warming, this is well done, kind of wish i waited til Christmas to drink it.

22 oz bottle thanks to Vince. Pours black with a huge bubbly tan head. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, pine resin and vanilla. The flavor is bittersweet chocolate with a healthy amount of hop bitterness. Full body with a foamy thick soft mouth feel and a long chocolaty finish. This is last years so its not as hopy as Ive heard its supposed to be. Regardless, this is a great Porter, now Ive got to get my hands on a fresh one.

Bottle. Christmas came a little early for my this weekend. Santa was very good to me indeed. Wrapped up inside this gift was a jet black body with a tight tan head. Notes of chocolate, dark sugars, roasted malts and winter spices. Smooth and creamy. Im glad the holidays are right around the corner so I can pick up another one of these.

22 oz. bottle shared at Logans 2009 pre-GABF Party.  Cola-like pour.  Cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove aromas.  Light chocolate, toffee, and nutmeg flavors.  Thin palate.  Alcohol not really present.  Good.

22oz bottle 9/16/09 (Binnys Naperville)-Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of hops, rioasted malt, chocolate, and slight coffee. Taste of hops followed by the roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. This medium bodied brew is very well balanced and quite taste. Great little twist on the Porter style. Great Brew.

When I popped the cap and took a whiff I knew this was going to be very, very good. This beer was black with a foamy, mocha colored head. It wasnt pitch black as some red tints could be seen if held up to the light. The smell was really sweet and enticing with a subtle aroma of roasted coffee beans. The taste, WOW! The taste was very chocolatey, sweet, roasty, coffee-like, amazing. The hops were also noticeable in the back and the aftertaste, almost minty. I have to buy several bottles of this when it is released, I cant believe how good this was.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-23-2007 15:26:50
Bottle thanks to my secret santa. Aroma of chocolate malt, chocolate, pine. Flavor primarily of milky chocolate notes, a touch of vanilla. Milky and creamy. Nice stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2010 bottle courtesy of shawnm213, thanks! super dense ruby pour, black for practical purposes. very little head that dissapears quickly with minimal spotting. nose is excellent, of a huge roasted, woody hopped coffee. taste is nice and warm, roasy and chocolaty. strong coffee and burnt aftertaste, but not burnt coffee.

RE:RATE- a much fresher bottle bumps this from a 3.9 to a 4.3 .  hop profile is much nicer, huge!  has a ccb cedar quality from the hops, spicy.  very nice stuff.  i really want to try this as fresh as possible! if the body were a lil thicker with a denser pour it would be into 4.6 territory.

Pour starts off a bit weak, the liquid is dark with some red highlights, the head is disappointing. A crown forms with some good lacing which saves this from average territory.

Smell is good and robust, I can smell it with the glass a few feet away. Chocolate, Molasses, a bit of a hop background. Milk, cream, a light roasted scent are also present.

Tastes fairly different than most porters I have had, because there is a hop presence, but unlike gonzo porter which I felt was more a dark IPA than a hoppy porter, they intermingle rather well with the chocolate and creamy tastes, neither really overpowering, but working in a balanced fashion. Interesting and good.

Mouth is medium in body and carbonation. No complaints here. I realize it isnt a stout, but I think this would be interesting in a thicker fashion.

Bottle.  Pours black with a thick light tan head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt, very sweet.  Flavor of sweet malt, chocolate malt, some lactose notes.  Pretty bland and boring really; Im quite underwhelmed.  Too sweet and not complex at all.  Meh
6/4/6/3/12 Ɠ.1/5)
Black in color with a large tan head. Aroma is of hops, coffee, and roasted malts. Taste is of roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, and hops.

22 oz bottle.  Pours black with a very large tan head.  Aroma is rich, deep chocolate and vanilla, some dark fruits.  Strong flavors of smoke, coffee, and bitter cocoa backed by vanilla and cream.  Lasting bitter coffee finish.  This is exactly what an imperial porter should be.

Bomber. Pour is deep brown/black with a small dark brown head. Huge roasted malts, coffee, and some piney hops to the nose. Flavor is damn good with roasty goodness throughout and finishing with coffee. Very nice brew and damn drinkable.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle 66cl. @ home.[ Trade by Bobby91w ]. Clear dark black color with a large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, coffee, moderate hoppy, grass. Flavor is light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090606]

22oz bottle shared by photomike.   Black with a medium beige head.   The aroma is just outstanding; a mix of potent tropical fruit hoppiness (mostly pineapple, with a good dose of ripe grapefruit) and subtle dark chocolate.   If you close your eyes, you might almost think IPA, but the chocolate is also unmistakable.   The flavor also has plenty of tropical fruit and dark chocolate, with a dry, earthy, almost smokey quality as well.   The finish is dry and earthy with a medium bitterness that isnt nearly as intense as the hop aroma and flavor.   Not nearly as thick thick or sweet as I had expected, and I really like that.   This drinks much easier than you might think, in a sharp departure from a certain stout that FFF makes, with a medium body and moderate carbonation.   This was an awesome and pretty unique beer.   Reminded me of Stone 11th, but more toward the porter end of the continuum.

Black pour with light brown head. Aroma is hoppy, sweet malt, and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, sweetness, little bitter.  The hops and the malt give this brew a great taste. They meld together well to give the complexbeer a great taste. As most good/great beers, as it warms in your hands, the taste magnifys for the best.
Great beer.  Mixture of porter and stout, with the best of both worlds.  Pours dark like a stout, with a porter aroma.  Flavor of chocolate and roasted malts.  Tastes the same.

650ml bottle from Khans, Indianapolis.  Pours a rich brown with a mocha head that lasted the entire glass and left lots of lacing.  Rich roast chocolate aroma and flavour with a nice hop bitterness in the finish.  Rich, think mouthfeel, and it only got better as it warmed.  Very nice porter indeed.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2010 rerate with fresh 2010 bottle.  pours a deep brown with a big foamy tan.   notes of coffee,  dark chocolate, and floral hops. Aweome interplay between fresh roast and pine and flowery hop notes.  Sticky, yet very smooth mouthfeel.  Awesome beer.   When fresh, cant be beat.

Source:  22 oz bottle at a tasting in Nashville. Glass: Snifter. Appearance: Poured a dark brown color with a one finger beige head.  Aroma:  Chocolate and vanilla, with nuts and a hint of roast.  A lot of hops present Flavor: Roasted malt body with a background of chocolate and vanilla.  Very hoppy. Palate:  Full body with soft carbonation.Overall:  Pretty solid.  Very hoppy, this was a bit of a surprise.

bottle poured a dark nutty brown with a nice frothy almost brown colored head that left espresso like foam on the surface. aroma has earthy malt, chocolate, bitter coffee, faint spice, and some hops layered over the top. first sip is nice and rich with chocolate and earthy malt. light touches of spice, roast, and a perfect level of hops.

Bottle from StFun.  Thanks Josh!  Pours a clean dark black with a beautiful thick brown head that immediately draws to mind whipped hot chocolate.  But the good hot chocolate, with actual chocolate in it, not that crap with the little blond girl and sad excuses for marshmallows.  Huge pine and floral hops which is impressive since A) Ive been a lazy bum and havent opened this in a timely fashion its May already, so its held up very well in spite of my neglect.  And near the end of May to boot.  And B) its a porter.  Really neat to get one that blurs the line between styles.  Behind the hops theres a nice roast malt note, and a touch of bitter chocolate, smoke, and leather.  Smells amazing.  Medium to thick mouthfeel, leathery.  Nice spiciness aided by the lively carbonation.  Big roast characteristic on the finish giving it a nice bitterness, but a very refined one at that.  Remarkably good, and yet another FFF beer that makes me miss them distributing to NY.

Bottle, courtesy someone. Dark brown thick pour, wet head, sticky ring of lacing. Nose is very hoppy, nice spicy and vanilla, some chocolate. Dry chocolate flavors, some roast, some caramel. Nice and full-bodied, although I hesitate to call it a porter because its so damn hoppy. Thats 3F for ya.

Thanks to Bobby91w for sending this one my way. Pours a deep, dark brown - almost black - with a light tan head. Honest to God, the first thing I smell is cola. Afri cola, for those who may remember that one. Some chocolate as well, and a very mild note of roasty coffee. Flavor brings out the coffee a bit more. Certainly malt-forward, and I can actually taste the warm Mexican sugar in there, too. The palate is nice - a crisp carbonation, but it doesnt have that dry finish that I usually look for in darker brews. Nutty sweet, and smooth for sure, but having discovered the bliss that is a good impy stout, porters just arent my style.

Wow!  Wasnt expecting too much already having my favorite Porters and not looking for another one to compete, but this is one of the better Porters Ive ever had.  Dark pour, opaque, short head.  Very very nice palate.  Smooth, soft, silky.  Touch of carbonation to give a crisp finish.  Chocolate!  Subtle flavors - coffee of course - not over done.  Think I actually prefer this to Founders Porter - while excellent, this feels more sophisitcated.  Will definitely purchase again.

The smell is slight hops, malts, roast, coffee, and chocolate.  The looks is brown to black in color with a nice beige colored head.  The taste is slight citrus hops mixing well with malts, roastiness, chocolate, sweet, and smooth.

bottle poured a dark nutty brown with a nice frothy almost brown colored head that left espresso like foam on the surface. aroma has earthy malt, chocolate, bitter coffee, faint spice, and some hops layered over the top. first sip is nice and rich with chocolate and earthy malt. light touches of spice, roast, and a perfect level of hops that allows the porter to shine.

22 oz. bottle (2008), in a snifter. A solid porter, but a tad overrated in my view- not Christmas-sy enough. Ar: Pine, allspice, toasted malt, chocolate, Brie and strong floral hops ala Alpha King. Ap: Dense black color w/ a deep brown pour. Robust tan head w/ good retention leaving plenty of lacing. Fl: Chocolate, chicory, roasted malts and hop oils. Pa: Thin. A solid, complex beer- FFF never disappoints!
Pours a very dark brown/amber. Nose is surprisingly hoppy, with some coffee, slight cherry and chocolate. Flavor is surprisingly not hoppy. Chocolate, spice and bready, with slight hops.

Poured from a bomber to a Delirium Tremens Snifter.

Appearance - This is definitely a porter from the dark side... No light is shining through this one. An easy pours creates a 1 finger creamy tan head. After the head dissipates, the walls of the glass are covered with lace, if you could even call it lace, see as it is as solid as I have ever seen.

Smell - Smells like your average everyday porter. Having a hard time pulling the scents out of this one. All I can pick up is chocolate. Maybe a little bit of spice? After this warmed up a bit, I was starting to get some very floral earthy hop smells. Very unexpected and very welcomed! This one smells great!

Taste - My taste buds are having a hard time as well tonight. I am picking up some spices, like in the smell. A little nutty too. I am starting to pick up some roasted malt and hops! Wow here come the hops! What a surprise, those hops came out of nowhere! I wish I would have tried this fresh, would have been ridiculous...

Mouthfeel - It is a little watery for my tastes, I was hoping for something a little fuller. I have been drinking a lot of motor oil lately though (RISs), so that might be skewing the mouthfeel of this a little. 

Drinkability - Because it is not too thick, it doesnt weigh me down like what I am used to. This makes this VERY drinkable for me. The taste was definitely pleasant as well. When the hops came out, it became phenomenal! I should have tried this one back at Christmas! This should be awesome fresh and should be pretty good with a couple years on it as well. Guess I will just have to wait and see.

Poured the whole dang bottle into a ridiculously huge tulip glass and looked upon a rather nice ruby tinged brown beer with light tan foam.  The concoction smells rather nice, a combination of American hops, little bit of citrus, maybe some pine, and chocolaty malt sweetness.  The flavor is happily complex, starts with malt sweetness and a twinge of hop bitterness, moves into some chocolate, then some kind of tea like flavor (that was far too present in the bottle of Black Sun I had, but pleasant here), and finishes off with a nice bitter roasted coffee aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is moderate.  Overall, this is a good beer.

Pours very dark brown - nearly black, with a creamy tan head that is well retained and leaves a coating of lace on the glass.  Inviting aroma of chocolate, licorice, floralcitric/grapefruity hoppiness, and mango.  The flvor in this one does not dissapoint - sweet roasted malts, dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and subtle smokiness play very well with the resinous, citrusy hops.  Substantial mouthfeel with smooth carbonation.    This stuff is just outstanding.

Rated 1/10/09. "Massive head, thick and brown. A lot of carbonation. Very dark. Roast on aroma, leather too. Sweet coffee and cocoa notes. Alcohol hides well. Syrupy. Decent texture -- a little fizzy at first, but fine by the end."

2008 Bottle - Pours out a thin dk brown with a massive mocha coloured head...aroma is cocoa malty, coffee, and some wood bitters...flavour is bold without being too over the top, nice sweet roast coffee on the front end that turns into a spicy, lingering bitter finish...very, very nice!
pours black with small tan head. nice spice on the nose with hops coming out front. coffee, chocolate, and a little spice i couldnt figure out through out. great christmas warmer!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2010 Pours black with a sandy head. Pretty bubbly. Smells like a christmas tree... mostly pine hop nose, with hints of chocolate, coffee, and grapefruit. Flavor is similar to smell, but with an increase in roasted malt and finishing with slightly bitter hops. Pretty tasty stuff.
Bottle @ jbrus. Dark color, brownish head. Aroma of coffee, spices, chocolat, cocoa. HIgh carbonation, which disturbs the taste actually. Bit off-balanced.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2012 Poured a dark brown with a nice head.  Very nice lacing.  Aroma was roasted malts and hops, with hints of chocolate, vanilla, and a little bit brown sugar.   The flavor was the same, but I really noticed a hoppy bite in the finish.  I have another aging and may break out at the first sign of cold this coming fall.

Bottled @ Jbrus. Aroma is herbal/vegetable/spive like with coffe and chocolate. Black coloured beer with a beige head. The taste is sweet, has coffee, chocolate, some roast. Carbonated. Medium bodied. Nothing special.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2015  Bomber from the beer locker. Knew it would cellar well but the appearance of snow reminded me to uncap this holiday gift. Poured murky, black/brown with a mid-tan, foamy, head and good, curtainy webs of lacing. The nose was initially dry, a little grain, with a slight sweetness, roasted coffee, and chocolate notes. The flavor mimicked the aroma except for the the big, bitter hop taste. A creamy mouth feel and dry finish followed. Definitely a hopped up, big Porter. 
 Enjoyed again at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. on tap. Appearance +.1
Recently shared a 2011 bomber with friends, and this time around, I detected a bit of toffee and vanilla in the nose. Enjoyed again on tap for the season at Lunar Brewing Co.. Added aroma notes of molasses, dark fruit, and star anise to the list. Full bodied and heavily roasted, with a lingering earthy & roasted nature to the hop bitterness in the flavor. HO HO!

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Aroma of veggies, herbs, chocolate and coffee. Opaque colour, beige head, good lace. Veggies, coffee and bitterness. Straightforward and a bit off-balance. Not bad, but nothing special.

Bottle, shared @ jbruss place. Chocolate, cacao and licorice in the aroma. Spicy flavor (nutmeg, cardemom). Malty sweetish with coffee and Koetjesrepen (cheap Dutch chocolate for children without cacao). Spicy in the finish.

22oz bottle.  Pours the darkest brown known to man with a nice 2 finger beige head that left some spotty lacing.  Aromas of toffee, chocolate.  Taste was much of the same while the finish was very smooth and bloody delightful! (British accent)
Tasting session at jbrus. Bottled. Opaque black, thick brown head. Very malty nose, chocolate. Highly carbonated, coffee in flavour. Bitter finish. Lacking some complexity imho.

suckered into purchasing another 3F!..its like crack! ... .. pours a dark black witha good head ring .. . .nice roast level, latte ... hides the abv well .. has a good flavour spectrum from coffee to chocolate monkey .. i like it, classy! ..you gonna come and shake my monkey tree again!!

Granted Im not much of a porter guy, but I expected more from a FFF release.  It looks great....like bpitch black tar in the glass, but the aroma and taste is a little off.  It is powerful and thick, but I cannot say I really liked the flavor.

Pour was dark brown and black with a mocha head. Aromas of sweet malt, hops and cocoa. medium light body and very smooth. Flavors are lovely with roasty  malt, molasses and chocolate. Very easy to drink. Finish is sweet and light hoppy bitterness. One of the better Porters I have had.

From StFun via trade.  The pour was dark with ruby on the fringes.  A thin tan head formed and created spots of lacing.  The aroma was sugary chocolate, roasted malts and some light citrus and floral hops.  The flavor was milk chocolate, roasted, smoky malt and some light citrus hops.  It sounds like Im describing more of IS, but it really tasted like a porter with hops on the finish.  The mouthfeel was almost full in body, very easy going down.
bottle, pitch black color, a little brown foam, aroma of leather, hops, bean curd, coffee, flavor is great mix of coffee, chocolate, some praline, hops are hidden until the finish

Pours death black with nice tan head. Aroma is coffee, molasses, caramel, roast, coffee, chocolate, and the slightest hop presence. Every aspect of the style is covered. Flavor skirts the line between porter and imperial stout. Roast is most evident, though sweet molasses and caramel make their way in with vigor. Balance is exceptional. Palate is thick, rich, and savory. Three Floyds comes though with another delicious sample.

Black pour with dissipating  pour.  caramel, chocolate hints, dark fruits in the nose. hint of hops.  Excellent presence in the mouth, robust roast and fruit.  chocolate and a hint of mocha along with some slight date/prune hints makes this a porter for the ages.

pitch black pour, not quite as viscous as a stout, with a small tan head. Aroma is heavy with roasted malt, coffee, caramel, with a slight citrus hop presence. Flavor is excellent- lots of roasty malt, definite hops, and a classic porter aftertaste. Really nice smooth palate, really good porter.

22oz bottle from drewbeerme, thanks Andrew. Very dark pour with just a little glow when held up to the light. Chocolate aroma, a little smokey. Get some coffee and more smokiness in the flavor, a little bitter as well, this is really good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Snifter.  Aroma is malt, hops, sugar.  Black color with dark tan head thats really nice.  Carbonation is obvious.

A rich, smoky, hoppy, malty flavor.  Really nice balance with a nice subtle taste of smoke in the end, like a good porter.  I usually dont hold with porters very much but this one is very good.

Bottle, sampled at Woodshop Quad. Pours a deep dark brown-black with a tan ring. Intense aroma, of malt, chocolate, and molasses. Taste is rich and sharp, malt, chocolate, wood, pine hops. Lingering sharpness. Huge and tasty.

Pitch black, dark motor oil colour. Head was medium sized. Aroma is mocha- roasted coffee beans, spices and cinnamon. Taste is super creamy, chocolatey with smokey undertones. Finishes soft with barbeque notes. Interestingly enough it had some wierd bananna notes in it as well. Maybe like a bananna split? Anyway- good stuff!

22 ounce bottle split in pint glass.  (Whats with the snifter recommendation for everything?)   Dark brown black with lasting dense head and full lace.  Fresh green American hop chocolate and coffee aroma.  Dark chocolate roasted coffee medium dark fruit with a bursting fresh green hops finish.  This is not a traditional porter.  But it is fucking outstanding.  One of my new favorite beers.  Medium body and medium-low carbo for a nice soft mouthfeel.  Complex, fresh, unique and out of this world.

22 oz. bottle - Pours sark with large tan head.
Aroma - bakers chocolate, vanilla and musty hops.
Flavor - More of a earthy dunkel taste with hops, chocolate and hops.
Palate - light to medium mouthfeel with averge carbonation. Finish is slightly dry with lingering musty hop flavor.
Overall - A decent porter but not that impressed.

Bottle thanks to some cool ass guy from my fantasy football league! Havent had this since I lived in Chicago four years ago....a welcome beer to revisit! Pours dark brown with out of control head that overflows with the lightest pour; managed to save most of it, though. Smooth roasty mix of malt with moderate dark fruit and a very unique sweetness. Big bitterness for a porter of any kind, but it melts together pretty nicely. Not too heavy, and I could drink this all winter...

22 oz. Nearly black pour, white head. Surprisingly piney aroma, some peat and roast malt. Flavor is also surprisingly crisp, very dry and hoppy. This over-rides the earthy malt, chocolate and coffee. Nearly creamy, but the bittyness hurts the mouthfeel a bit. Finishes with some linering coffee and hop bitterness. Really too much hops for the style. More alcohol warming as well than I would prefer, even though it is not that terribly high an abv. Drinkability is pretty meh. Unfortunately I had rather high expectations for this. Hopefully with some age this will mellow out a bit.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Large dark pour with dark tan head. Chocolate, caramel, and light coffee step out on the aroma. Full rich choco flavor with a coffee kicker. Full bodied with very good carbonation. Not the huge hop bomb I expected but damn nice.

22 oz bottle.  Near heavenly aroma on this one, tons of roasted, nutty malts, dark chocolate, coffee beans, and very pronounced hop backing as well of standard yet always interesting 3Fs variety.  Nice pour as well, small-medium creamy beige head, mostly dissipates, with a little lacing, and a color of dark sepia.  The first thing I notice upon sipping this one is the excellent balance for a strong and very hop heavy porter. Less heavy on the body than i remembered but definitely not in bad way, it also very drinkable and can easily be drunk as a session beer.  A good amount of roastiness fills the flavor profile throughout, could also be described as smokey as well.  Semi sweet/ semi rich black/chocolate malt and minor sugar crystals come through, but it is not all that chocolaty nor coffee flavored either as maybe i would expect. Just a very solid combination of darker yet not overly sweet malt.  Hop backing is as evident as any as i can even describe them to be slightly citrus mango and floral in style.  Maybe this one wouldnt be for anyone nor would i expect most people to enjoy it quite like i did, but i must say that alpha klaus is definitely my kind of beer.  Wow, very hard to beat.
Bottle (2006) at ØLbaren (thanks Lars). Black - brown head. Coffee, borned, berries, chocolate, licorice, light smokey notes, smoothness, nice hoppy. Nice - not fantastic.

22oz bottle aged since 2007. Pours a very dark brown, almost black body with a big, creamy and frothy, two-fingerwidth, brown head that dissipates slowly and remains heavily laced. Damn good looking porter. Aroma of chalky milk chocolate, dry coffee, and a good amount of cascade-ish grapefruit hops giving it a slightly earthy quality. Slightly roasty and a touch of vanilla. A lot of nice smells, I just wish it was a little stronger in the nose. Flavor is pretty similar, but the earthy citrus hop is more evident than the standard roasty character in a normal porter. Semi sweet and lightly chocolated in the beginning before drying out in the finish with a distinct grapefruit bitterness and a touch of roast and coffee. Theres a nice soft maltiness throughout that gives off a very lightly burnt taste. Palate is light to medium bodied and slightly higher in carbonation than most porters giving it a tingly feel. Overall, I love FFF for bending the rules when it comes to style and hop additions, but I think when Im looking for a big porter, Im more interested in a creamy, chocolate roast taste rather than this particular one. I think the added hops make this very flavorful, but too quick on the tongue. Definitely a great porter that I would recommend to a lot of people, but I have a hard time puting this at the top of my list of favorites. Despite that, I still thoroughly enjoyed it.

22 oz bottle. Pours a jet black color, but a lightweight consistency, with almost no head. Smells of malt, hops, and coffee (reminds me of Alpha King in smell, but with some coffee accents), Tastes of coffee and hops (too many hops for my liking, but the right amount of coffee). Strong mouth taste, with some tingly feeling. Easy swallow though, with a nice coffee aftertaste. Overall very good.

Thanks to STLWill for this one.  I thought I had it previously but this was my first time.  It is an excellent beer.  Full, heavy mouthfeel.  Big hop aroma for a porter.
